name: Crean, Simon, MP
text:
—As I have predicted to this House before, the GST deal done between the Prime Minister and Senator 
 Lees has produced a dog's breakfast for the so-called new tax system. That deal has delivered a complex nightmare for small business and all businesses in some sectors, particularly the retailing sector. I said when we were dealing with the final passage of the original GST legislation through this House that there would be nothing surer than the fact that the government would be back here seeking many amendments to fix up the dog's breakfast they have created. Today we have a further helping.
People should remember that this GST package has already been amended a total of 302 times in 36 different pieces of legislation—those figures according to Chamber Research—but that was done via a slow and tortuous process that lasted weeks, and it involved much toing-and-froing between the houses. It would seem that the government has become a bit more efficient in its amending process, because in this one bill alone,  A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999 , there are a further 454 amendments—more amending than even it managed through the whole original GST debate. That is 454 amendments in one hit. Incredible but correct! The great new simpler tax system is not three months old and already we have 756 amendments. It is a bit like the Bruce Springsteen song `57 channels and nothing's on'. Today it is Peter Costello's 454 amendments and he still has it wrong. The only difference is Bruce Springsteen is the boss and Peter Costello just wants to be.
 This bill proposes to fix up hundreds of mistakes and anomalies in the original legislation with 454 amendments. If the government cannot get it right now, how is small business supposed to be able to get it right? How can people plan for their new way of business life under a totally uncertain taxation environment? The answer is they cannot. But it is not just the GST which is full of mistakes; the Treasurer has also mucked up on the luxury car tax, on the wine equalisation tax and on the ACCC's price monitoring powers. Make no mistake: the reason the GST has become such a dog's breakfast for Australian business is the way in which the government went 
 about it—with excessive secrecy and overblown rhetoric.
Australian businesses are hoping it will not be the same with business tax reform. We have called for bipartisanship on business tax reform for months now. It is pleasing that the government has finally conceded, at least on the surface, the importance of such an approach. The Treasurer and I had a useful meeting last night. But the truth is that business needs the certainty in its tax arrangements that goes beyond one electoral cycle, and that can be achieved only through support by the only two parties that can form a government. We will see if the government is genuine about trying to reach that agreement.
The trouble with business tax reform is that we do not yet have a complete package. We will get legislation for stage 1 tomorrow. How far it goes in relation to the announced items remains to be seen. But the problem is that we do not have stage 2 yet—the government's response to literally hundreds of Ralph recommendations. We will be looking closely at this legislation to see if it passes the test that not only Labor but also the government has set. Labor has said the full response to the business tax package must pay for itself. It must be revenue neutral. As the government's response stands at the moment, it does not pay for itself. What the government calls stage 1 is $3.8 billion short over six years, $2 billion short over four years, on the Treasurer's own admission.
However, the package could pay for itself if the government bites the bullet on the hard decisions needed in stage 2. We need more than assurances that it has a `disposition' to take those decisions. We need to know, for example: will the government water down the trusts legislation? Will it put in place general antiavoidance measures to prevent conversion of income to capital gains? And will it act sufficiently on the alienation of personal services income and on the treatment of non-commercial losses? These are all-important policy considerations and integrity measures to underpin the proposed package.
If the government does all of these things properly the package could pay for itself and, if it pays for itself, Labor can support it. But 
 we will not be fobbed off by vague promises. We will not accept the proposition that will allow the government to hand out all of the lollies to the business community and sort out how they pay for them later. It cannot just be a wing and a prayer and a `Trust me I am the Treasurer' approach. When has it ever been the case that revenue is counted in the bottom line for measures the government has not yet decided to do? That is why stage 2 is so important—not just what is in it but also when it is announced—because we want the announcements made in time for the Senate inquiry to build those decisions into its investigations. And, finally, we will be carefully scrutinising the stage 1 legislation to ensure that it includes appropriate integrity measures.
Returning now to the detail of the bill, it is not feasible to examine each amendment in detail in this speech. There are simply too many of them—454, as I indicated before. The explanatory memorandum runs for 79 pages simply to describe the measures. This was a government that was going to simplify and shorten the tax system. They are the amendments and the explanatory material just from this little number alone.
However, I want to touch on a few of the major details that are contained in the proposals. First, in the area of rules for small business, in order to minimise the administrative nightmare that small business is facing—the nightmare on main street, to use the Treasurer's phrase—there will be a special regime for small retailers selling both tax-free and taxable items. This is for the mixed business—what is in, and what is out, including the cooked chook with a thermometer, the bagged lettuce, the canned soup and all of those things.
The government is proposing to introduce so-called simplified accounting measures. This is at item 111 of schedule 1 of the bill and is briefly explained at page 25 of the explanatory memorandum. A small business operator can elect to be covered by the system, which simply applies a percentage figure to his or her total sales. This percentage is supposed to be a reflection of the average proportion of sales which are taxable without the need to 
 separately account for each sale. The benefits of such an approach are simplicity and, therefore, a reduction in otherwise unsustainable compliance costs.
However, a number of problems still remain with this approach. For example, this system applies only to dealings between the retailer and the Australian Taxation Office. It does not affect the law regarding whether or not a particular item is taxable or non-taxable. All actual pricing of items will have to be on the correct basis—either with GST or GST free. But how will consumers know whether a particular product is subject to the GST? The answer is: they will not, because the Democrats and the government conspired to ensure that they should not know. They together, in doing this dirty deal, took the conscious decision to dud consumers by denying consumers the detail on receipts of the GST component of what they pay.
The Democrats and the government deliberately voted down Labor's amendment to give consumers the right to know how much GST they are paying when they purchase their goods and services. They took the position that they have created a nightmare for small business; now they want a nightmare for consumers but they want to hide this nightmare. We will give the coalition members in this House the opportunity to revisit this issue. We want to see how representatives of the coalition government in this House—in particular, those who hold marginal seats—vote when it comes to Labor putting that amendment back up in this House. Having imposed this unfair tax that the majority of Australian people do not want, they now want to hide it. They want to vote down any proposals that seek proper disclosure. We are going to try again to get that disclosure.
We opposed the GST, but if you are going to have it you at least ought to be game enough to tell people what they are paying. If you are going to have it, at least tell them the amount that they are incurring each time they go into a shop or a supermarket and each time they have to pay a bill for services. At the moment, they will get no disclosure, because this government does not want it. They want 
 to introduce this so-called fair tax, and then they want to hide it.
Mr Hockey interjecting—
—We know the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation is getting excited: it is getting close to lunchtime, and that is when he does all his important business. He is on the record as having said that, so I am surprised he is still here wandering around.
Mr Hockey interjecting—
—Oh, he is going to do us over on that. I wait to see it. I am living in fear. I am trembling in my boots. It will be after lunch, Minister?
—Question time!
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the minister will both restrain themselves.
—Will we have the so-called simplified system for small business? As is usual from this government, we do not have the rules at all. Having said that they are going to introduce the simplified measures, they do not even lay the rules down in this legislation. Just as the diesel grant scheme was the nightmare on highway 1, just as it was completely unclear in defining the boundaries of the conurbation areas in which this grant does and does not apply—which is a piece of information you would have to accept is vital for truckers and trucking companies in determining whether they have to pay the diesel tax—and just as the previous legislation did not define those boundaries, neither does this legislation define the proportions.
The proportions of sales that small business will have to pay GST to the Taxation Office on are not defined in this legislation. It is the same incompetence that is associated with the diesel grants legislation duplicated in relation to small businesses and the proportions they have to pay to the Taxation Office. Apart from this legislation, there will be power—under a new division—for the commissioner to determine those proportions. But the determination, when it is made, is not a disallowable instrument. Understand this 
 point: what may be the most important piece of a regulation under the whole GST mess for many small businesses will not, according to this legislation, be reviewable by the parliament. So much for a government that calls for greater accountability.
There will apparently be more than one option for small businesses, but the bill does not say how many there will be. There are also rules about when taxpayers can and cannot elect to use options and when they can and cannot revoke options. This so-called simplified system is very complicated indeed. But we still do not have the crucial details so that our many small retailers and charities can examine whether or not the options suit them. They have more legislation and more complexity to deal with, but they have no greater certainty.
On the food anomalies, three specific issues are addressed. First, still water will be GST free irrespective of the packaging in which it is sold. Get this: currently, the legislation—this dog's breakfast of tax—says that bottled still water is GST free but that if that same brand of still water is in a cask it gets the tax. I could be standing here with two glasses of water—essentially the same product—and asking the minister to tell me under their previous legislation which one is taxed and which one is not. This sounds like a very complicated system to me. It is a ridiculous situation in fact.
But while that particular anomaly is being addressed—now, if the water comes out of a cask, it does not attract the tax either—there remains another anomaly. Carbonated—bubbly—water, such as soda water, cops the tax under the new tax arrangements whereas the still water is exempt. That is a great simplification. That is the great streamlining that the Treasurer has claimed will be delivered. We will now have to have the bubble meters, together with the thermometers, and the dipsticks for the diesel, to work out when this tax applies and when it does not. What a farce!
The second food anomaly that this bill seeks to correct concerns milk. Unprocessed cow's milk is to be made subject to the GST, although processed milk will be GST free. 
 This will put milk processors in a cash flow negative position in the same way that meat processors are already. Dairy farmers will not be penalised in a cash flow sense. However, this means that unprocessed cow's milk will be taxable, while other unprocessed animal milks, such as goat's milk, will be GST free. It is another example of this growing mountain of anomalies that demonstrates that this dog's breakfast of a tax has different rules depending on the type of milk—whether it is processed or unprocessed, whether it is flavoured or not and whether it is for human or animal consumption. This is not simplification; it is a farce.
There are literally hundreds of other issues dealt with in the bill. The small business cash accounting threshold is to be increased from $0.5 million to $1 million. This is consistent with the figure announced in the business tax review and is supported by Labor. This will reduce the cash flow disadvantages which can accrue to businesses with a turnover of between $0.5 million and $1 million, but it will not protect those with a slightly higher turnover. They will still face the nightmare of being liable to pay GST on the goods and services they have invoiced to a client where they have not been paid for that invoice. This is a recipe for a cash flow crisis for these businesses.
The income tax treatment of GST is `clarified' on pages 49 to 59 of the explanatory memorandum. Some clarification: it takes 10 pages to clarify! This was supposed to be the simple system, but much of it was very complex. The general intention is that the GST should not impact on income tax liabilities for GST-registered taxpayers. The original provisions were supposed to achieve this, but the Treasurer mucked it up, as usual. This point was picked up by tax expert Geoff Lehmann, writing in the Australian some months ago. The point was that the existing provisions are deficient in a number of technical ways. This legislation will hopefully fix them but, given the track record of the government, do not bet on it. They said that the original legislation achieved the objective and they were wrong.
But the mistakes do not end there. This government cannot even get the exemptions right. Specifically, as the law currently stands, many health services will be subject to GST. There are technical drafting flaws in the exemptions for medicines which render such supplies as taxable at the moment. The bill claims to address these, but that is what the government said months ago. It does not end there. There are also technical flaws in the medical aids and appliance provisions which have rendered them taxable. A new credit is to be provided for vehicles leased prior to 2 December 1998—that is, when the GST legislation was introduced into the parliament—which are disposed of after the GST commences. This is estimated to cost around $150 million. This is at least partial recognition of the damage that the GST is doing to the leasing industry and to the motor vehicle industry in general. There have been many reports attesting to that fact. I am sure that my colleague the member for Kingston will be elaborating on that issue later in the debate.
In addition, the government has been forced to relax the 50 per cent market value test for supported accommodation supplied by charities. The new test will be 75 per cent—that is, only rents 75 per cent or more of market rental will be affected by the GST. Others will be GST free. Labor obviously welcomes this as a small recognition of the harsh treatment that charities and other non-profits get with the GST. It is in this area that the Democrats showed how weak and unprincipled they really were on the GST. They had every card in the negotiations with the government. They were essentially dealt a hand of nine no trumps. They bid six and won one. That is how good they were in the game that they found themselves in. They could not even negotiate any benefits—or rather any lessening of penalty—from the GST for the charitable and not-for-profit sectors. These are not businesses; these are organisations that provide essential community services, even more so these days given the government's cutbacks in vital areas.
We saw the impact in Victoria, where a change of government has been confirmed 
 today because the previous government was cutting services everywhere, particularly in regional Victoria, and the electors showed their displeasure. Here the Democrats were in a position to get some relief for these charitable and not-for-profit sectors, but they chose to run dead. As the reality of the impact of this capitulation by the Democrats arrives on the sector, even the Democrats who voted for the deal are starting to realise how dudded they were.
Because of the growing concerns of the charitable sector about the impact of the GST, Labor said the other day that it requires a full inquiry, and we will be seeking the support of the Democrats for such an inquiry. The impact of the GST on this sector is going to hit the charitable sector hard, and that means services are going to be hit hard. We need that factor properly inquired into. The diesel experience that the Democrats went through will reinforce those feelings as well, as transport operators come to understand the nightmare that they will inherit. They have to inform the Democrats, just as the charitable sector does, of the impact of their dirty deal.
On the question of insurance, item 12 to schedule 5 proposes an amendment to address a technical flaw in the election provisions concerning GST credits associated with insurance. That is on pages 71 and 72 of the explanatory memorandum. The provisions concerning the claiming of credits for GST paid on insurance policies are extremely complex, but they also have a potentially serious trap for the unwary. The claiming of GST credits on insurance policies by small business can lead to significant liabilities for the business concerned if the policy is actually activated, as payouts on the policy will be taxable to the claimant, not to the insurance company.
Before the election, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer said to small business, `Don't worry about the GST because you can claim a credit for it.' But they did not tell them that they could potentially face financial ruin if they did so. It has taken the insurance industry to alert their clients to the risks associated with this complex, unfair system. Indeed, insurers are now starting to offer insurance for 
 the potential cost of claiming GST credits. This is the new growth industry from the GST. This is a new service to advise on the horrendous impacts that no-one was ever told about. It is straight out of Monty Python.
The final area I want to explore is that of taxes and the imposition of the GST on top of existing taxes. Currently, under division 81, all taxes are subject to the GST unless the Treasurer makes an order to exclude them. The government always try to deny this, but it remains the case. Instead of clarifying what is in and what is out, the bill actually broadens the scope from taxes to also include all fees and charges. It is not just taxes; it is all fees and charges levied by Commonwealth, state, territory or local governments. The real agenda of the government is out. They want to have the power to increase all of the fees and charges, whether large or small, that other governments raise. Of course they will deny it, but that is what this bill gives them the power to do.
By definition, imposing a tax on a tax involves tax cascading, which is one of the reasons the government used to justify the GST being introduced. They wanted to stop tax cascading. They have created an environment for the new cascade—waterfalls breaking out all over the country in terms of local charges and levies. There will literally be hundreds of other provisions, many of which are very technical and not easily understood except by experienced technicians.
There is one other very serious matter that I want to touch on, and that goes to prices surveillance. There is a serious flaw in the powers of the ACCC to stop anticipatory price rises. The ACCC may monitor all prices throughout the transitional period. However, its enforcement powers with respect to all goods and services other than those where the sales tax has already been reduced do not commence until the GST implementation date—that is, 1 July next year. Therefore, if a business unreasonably raised its prices in anticipation of the GST before 1 July, the ACCC could not exercise its enforcement powers until 1 July next year. Clearly, the horse would have well and truly bolted by then. The proposed amendments will bring 
 forward the date of effect of the ACCC's enforcement so that it can exercise those powers immediately. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>A NEW TAX SYSTEM (INDIRECT TAX AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1999</title>

name: Baird, Bruce, MP
text:
—It was interesting, but not terribly illuminating, to hear the member for Hotham's speech on the new tax system legislation. He mentioned Bruce Springsteen and the Treasurer. One of Bruce's songs was about a working-class man, and the honourable member makes pretensions of being the real working-class man, but it is this side of the House that is in fact looking after the working man, that is providing the tax cuts they are all applauding and that is changing our tax system to provide the reforms for an efficient economy and for a private sector which will be able to operate without the complexities of the wholesale sales tax.
The member for Hotham has the audacity to come into the House and criticise some changes we have made in response to the community. As concerns are raised and as issues need to be addressed, we are refining the taxation system. But the reality is that, if you look at the changes that were made to the wholesale sales tax, these changes were in fact minuscule in comparison. These address some of the valid concerns that have been brought to the Treasurer. I am sure that every member of the House would applaud the fact that the government is listening to those concerns and making the changes.
Questions were raised by the shadow Treasurer in relation to tax cascading and tax on tax. One of the great advantages of a GST is that you will remove the whole question of tax on taxes, which is one of the distorting factors in the current system. This is the system in which those provisions of tax on taxes will be removed. It is effective, and I am not quite sure what he is proposing. In his criticisms, he is saying, `We want to avoid any possibility that this could happen'—when clearly he is saying it will not—`by keeping this amazing system that we currently have, which is often a tax on a tax on a tax.' These proposals are very sensible and logical and will make the GST even more effective.
Criticisms were made of the changes. The opposition did have the opportunity to join 
 with the government to make changes that they saw as necessary; instead it was the Democrats who took that opportunity. If they have criticisms now in terms of the arrangements that were made, it is a bit too late—the horse has bolted. They stand as an aside to the whole process; they are totally irrelevant and constantly criticising. All they can do is criticise. They have bagged the whole concept right from the start and they have criticised anything that has been put up.
It is very rare to hear the opposition support anything—everything is criticised because it goes to the whole crumbling edifice of saying that there is something wrong with the GST when the debate has moved on. The community has accepted it. Obviously there will be debate about various aspects of the implementation of it, and that is only appropriate when there are such significant and far-reaching reforms as we have seen. They are the most significant changes to the tax act for some 50 years, so it is appropriate that we make some minor changes to keep it in line with community expectations. These issues have been brought forward, and we believe the amendments are necessary.
As small business and community groups get to know the requirements of the exemptions and of bringing forward their suggestions, the great majority of small business will not have any problems complying with them—80 to 90 per cent of businesses will deal only with the basic provisions. The special provisions contained in this bill which have been designed to fit certain industries will not be hard for people operating in those industries to understand. Obviously, the amendments that are contained in this bill are appropriate to that particular sector.
A charity supplying accommodation will not be concerned with the wine equalisation tax. A car lessor will not be concerned with unprocessed cows milk being subject to a GST. But those people involved in the sectors for whose benefit these amendments have been brought do not find their particular section difficult to understand. Now that the Australian people have rejected Labor's outdated tax system, it is appropriate that they should focus on the aspects of the GST.
One of the important aspects mentioned in this bill is charities. There are some changes in terms of the way in which the ANTS bill will operate, and the bill also contains a number of provisions relating to charities. The bill identified which charities would be tax exempt and how they would apply for that status through the Australian business number registration system. So only those charities which are mentioned in the act will be subject to it. They have to apply for that registration, and then those donations will be tax deductible.
A charities consultative group, with the agreement of the Australian Democrats, has been set up to oversee the new taxation system and how it will affect the charities. It will make sure that charities are not disadvantaged overall. The Vos report, which looked hard at the general impact on charities, and the recommendations that were made by David Vos, who is a senior tax partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, have been very much accepted by the charities operating in Australia.
In terms of the way in which the charities operate, part of the coalition's social policy is about contracting out, wherever possible, the requirements that government has undertaken in the past but which could be more appropriately handled by charities. They are very much part of the mainstream in terms of the administration of welfare across-the-board. The bill will extend the definition of non-commercial suppliers of residential accommodation by charities. For organisations providing emergency accommodation to receive a tax benefit, they need charge only 75 per cent of the market value. The government realised that a 50 per cent requirement was too restrictive and would rule out many worthwhile groups.
The measure only applies to non-commercial supply of residential accommodation by charities, because the client income base contributions associated with residential accommodation are often only marginally above the current 50 per cent market value test. To not meet this test would make the supplier's input taxed as residential rents or taxable as commercial accommodation for 
 some boarding houses, which would significantly increase compliance costs. This is an important measure which will reduce compliance costs while maintaining the principle that all commercial supplies should be subject to GST. The 50 per cent market value test remains for other non-commercial supplies.
The next aspect I want to refer to is the question of preventing unfair price rises. Of course, part of the legislation provides the ACCC with the ability to review prices across-the-board and to impose significant penalties where it is clear that the implementation of the GST is being used by companies, both large and small, to exploit the opportunities for price rises that are not justified in terms of the introduction of the GST. Penalties of up to $10 million are provided for those who are clearly rorting the system and misusing the introduction of the GST for an increase in profitability of their operation.
Under the ANTS legislation, the ACCC can take action, and undoubtedly will take action in the future. The government has done its utmost through seminars across Australia and through booklets, ATO visits and support to ensure that there is little confusion in the community as to how the GST should be implemented. Those who deliberately try to profiteer will be penalised as a result of actions taken. The ACCC can issue a notice asking a company to explain their pricing policies under section 75AX. The commission can specify the maximum price the business can charge, but it will be up to the Federal Court to issue a penalty of up to $10 million for corporations or $500,000 for individuals who abuse the system.
Some concerns have been expressed, in this period before the GST is implemented, about signs going up saying that, due to the introduction of the GST, prices will go up as of 1 November—by seven per cent, 10 per cent or whatever. Clearly, that is not justified on any basis. It is about exploiting that opportunity to increase their profit base. This is unacceptable to the government, it is unacceptable to the community, and appropriate penalties will be introduced. To put the issue beyond any doubt, the government will amend the Trade Practices Act to ensure that the ACCC, in 
 addition to its post 1 July 2000 powers, will have powers to take immediate action in respect of any unreasonable price rises before 1 July 2000. So companies are very much put on notice that there is to be no price gouging, and this will certainly be of great benefit to the Australian consumer.
The next important aspect is helping business—particularly small business—operate with a mixture of tax systems. For small businesses that have some items which attract a GST and others that are GST-free, the problems of compliance will add to the difficulties of their operating. Therefore, the government will provide special rules so that the Commissioner of Taxation will be able to determine alternative, simpler methods of calculating GST liability for retailers selling such goods. For example, we know that the average corner store has a mixture of goods—whether it is sandwiches, which attract the GST, or fruit and vegetables, which do not, or confectionery, which does, or whatever. This is about providing an easy away of determining the general GST liability. I think that is appropriate. It will simplify the system. It will enable the average small retailer to go about their business without undue burden from compliance.
There is also a clarification in this bill of the definition of wine products so that the wine equalisation tax extends, as was intended, to fruit or vegetable wines and grape products such as wine cocktails, flavoured wines and a range of cream drinks. Of course, the wine equalisation tax amendments ensure that there is no windfall gain to suddenly increase the consumption of alcohol in Australia through wine being given special assistance in these measures.
There are a range of sensible measures in this bill which indicate that the government is listening to the community and which are in line with the overhaul of the taxation system. Several things are very clear. The first is that the government is listening to the community and making these changes. The second is that, at the end of the day, we will have an efficient tax system which will provide the most significant reforms in taxation that this country has ever seen, and will receive community 
 support. Not only will it provide for a new way of taxing, which will include in the net the service area; it will also provide significant reductions for exporters. It will provide significant reductions in the cost of cars, for example, which, for the average household, are a major expenditure. It will provide real incentives to employees by way of tax cuts and tax changes so that 80 per cent of the community will pay no more than a 30c tax rate. It will abolish some of the inefficient taxes such as BAD and FID and the bed tax.
These tax changes will be welcomed in the Australian community and in the business community. They will do much to stimulate economic growth and development in this country for the longer term. They will provide the basis to service the social security needs in this country. They will provide a system that is more easily understood which will not provide the distortions of the current system and of the wholesale sales tax system, with its many variations, inequities and unfairness. I support the provisions in this bill. They indicate a government that is concerned about economic efficiency and a better tax system and also one that responds to the needs of the community.
debate_title: <title>A NEW TAX SYSTEM (INDIRECT TAX AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1999</title>

name: Thomson, Kelvin, MP
text:
—The A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999  is an extraordinary bill. It is designed to fix up hundreds of mistakes and anomalies in the original GST legislation—that legislation that we were told would give us all a simpler tax system. In fact, if we look at schedule 1, it has 255 amendments, schedule 2 has 32 amendments, schedule 3 has 93 amendments, schedule 4 has four amendments, schedule 5 has 10 amendments, schedule 6 has 14 amendments, schedule 7 has 20 amendments and schedule 8 contains 26 amendments. All up, the government has before us 454 amendments, and you have to ask: when is it going to stop? I invite the government to tell the House when they think they have got their GST legislation correct. My colleague the member for Rankin has taken to referring to the new simplified tax system by weight of the legislation, so it is certainly not giving us simpler legislation.
It is certainly not possible to examine legislation of this character in detail, because the explanatory memorandum alone takes some 79 pages simply to describe the changes. We hear rumours that the government intends to gag debate on this legislation and that would be a matter of great concern. We have 454 amendments and 79 pages in the explanatory memorandum and we may not get the opportunity to debate it in any detail.
Let me come to some of the things that are more significant in this legislation. The first are the provisions dealing with small business. In order to do something to address the administrative nightmare that the GST unquestionably will be for retailers selling both tax-free and taxable items—for example, shops selling food and beverages—the government is proposing to introduce simplified accounting measures. Under these so-called simplified accounting measures a small business operator can elect to be covered by a system which simply applies a percentage to his or her total sales. The percentage is supposed to be a reflection of the average proportion of sales which are taxable without the need to separately account for each sale. The benefits of that approach would be simplicity and we would hope for a reduction in what are going to be otherwise horrendous compliance costs.
Nevertheless, there are some problems with this approach. The system only applies to dealings between the retailer and the tax office. It does not affect the law regarding whether or not a particular item is taxable or non-taxable. All pricing of items will have to be on the correct basis and there could be a problem here if some businesses decide to apply the GST to all sales and seek to reap a windfall by only remitting the proportion determined by the so-called simplified accounting measures. This is one of the reasons why Labor endeavoured to ensure that consumers would be protected by separately identifying the GST on receipts so that consumers would know exactly what they were paying by way of GST. It is something that we want to pursue again when we get this bill into its committee stage. Putting a similar GST percentage across industries assumes that 
 all retailers have the same profit margins on similar goods. That is just plain wrong and it would therefore benefit some retailers at the expense of others.
Once again, the legislation does not actually provide the detail to small business about what the percentages will be for separate industries. Indeed, it does not give us the definition of what the industries will be. It simply sets up a framework for the tax commissioner to issue such a determination. The determination is not, as things stand, to be a disallowable instrument and that is an issue that might be pursued either here or, indeed, potentially in the Senate. Once again, with the GST legislation we see the government not providing the sort of detail that businesses actually need in order to go about conducting their businesses.
Some of the comments concerning the impact of the GST on small business as it gets closer and small businesses are faced with the implementation of it are quite instructive. For example, the National Tax and Accountants Association has said:
Confusion reigns supreme as businesses attempt to calculate their new pricing policy under the GST . . . 
Mr Ray Regan, the President of the National Tax and Accountants Association, says:
Small businesses are in the worst position. Large businesses can obviously afford to pay for economic modelling to help them estimate their cost savings, but small businesses  cannot.
He goes on to point out that:
The cost savings estimates published by the Government in its ANTS are now no longer relevant. When the savings estimates were published by the Government, 10 taxes were to be abolished once the GST was introduced. The problem is that the savings estimates fail to consider that 8 out of the 10 taxes will still apply once the GST is introduced.
Mr Regan points out:
. . . this means the savings models provided by the Government are WRONG and cannot accurately be relied upon by businesses anymore!
He says:
. . . small businesses are crying out for help from the Howard Government because they want to do the right thing but there is no cost effective way for them to do it. 

Similar concern on behalf of small business has been expressed by the Certified Practising Accountants who recently conducted a small business survey which was released in the October edition of the CPA journal. The survey was conducted in Melbourne, as well as in some other cities, but they reported their Melbourne results. They indicated from this survey that many Melbourne based small business operators are overestimating their GST readiness and are, indeed, quite unprepared for the introduction of the new tax. Some 47 per cent of small businesses said they felt GST ready; nevertheless, key operational elements of the GST have not yet been announced and there is a lack of educative information.
 Kerrie Clayton, the small business adviser for the CPA, says that while half the businesses surveyed nationally said they were ready for the GST, that figure conflicts with the number of businesses which have actually sought advice, undertaken a review of their business operations, taken staff training into account or allocated funds. Small businesses are expressing some concern about the GST and its impact on them. Some 72 per cent of small businesses surveyed nationwide have not as yet spent any money in their preparations for the GST. For those that have spent money preparing for the GST, the national average was $553, with the Melbourne average almost double that at $1056.
The survey indicates that some 49 per cent of businesses did not know what their estimated total expenditure to get their business GST ready was going to be. For those that could give an estimate, average expected expenditure to get business GST ready was $2,618. Once again, some 48 per cent of businesses could not estimate how much time they will spend getting ready for the GST. For those that could give an estimate, the average time they expected to spend to become GST ready was 64 hours. They further say that some 72 per cent of businesses believe that there will be some staff training required for the GST.
That is something of the background of the effect of implementation of the GST on small business. In terms of giving even more of a backdrop to the problems facing small busi 
 ness in this area as they endeavour to prepare for the GST, it is regrettable that the government has done so little by way of supporting small business in the GST area and in preparing them for the implementation of the GST, because small business really is doing it tough and finding the environment increasingly competitive and increasingly difficult. I regret that the best that the government seems to be able to do is to come into the House today with a bill of some 454 amendments and say to small business, `Here are some more amendments that we want you to deal with.'
 As an example of the background of difficulties that small businesses face, I draw to the attention of the House the present situation in the Healesville community, where Coles Myer has given very generous terms to Australia Post to remove its post office from the place where it presently is, in the main street of the town, and take it along to the Coles Myer redeveloped area. Of course, securing the Healesville Post Office as a key tenant increases the resale value of that complex when the Coles Myer property development is put up for sale. Nevertheless, it is a move regarded by the Healesville people as anti-community and anti-rural Australia and as a sign that Australia Post is turning its back on a community that has funded it for generations and that, instead of allying itself with the small businesses in the main street of Healesville, it is allying itself with a large and powerful chain, to the detriment of the local community.
This has been a matter of concern to the Healesville Chamber of Commerce and Industry. We had Bob Treller from that chamber saying that if this leads to empty shops in the main shopping strip, this will be very bad for the town and have a ripple effect on the town, with small traders struggling as a result. Originally we saw Coles Myer say, back in February of this year, that in developing this project the company would be looking at growth potential under existing circumstances and not at the expense of established businesses. What they then went on to do was to poach one of the most longstanding of established businesses, Australia Post—
—The honourable member for Wills does seem to be drifting away from the subject matter of the bills before the House.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do think that this is an important backdrop, because it helps us to understand the sorts of problems that small businesses are facing in towns like Healesville, as they prepare for the introduction of the GST. I note your ruling, and I conclude on this area by expressing concern that Australia Post has been unwilling to listen to the views of local Healesville residents, some 300 of whom marched recently against what Australia Post has been doing, and they have not accepted Australia Post's compromise proposal for a licensed post office in the main street. They think that may indeed even lead to the end of their post office full stop, and be privatisation by stealth. That is something that the Healesville community is rejecting. I hope that the government, through Australia Post, is prepared to revisit this issue and do the right thing by the Healesville community.
A second issue which is addressed in this legislation concerns what might best be described as food anomalies. The first of those is that still water will be GST free, irrespective of the packaging in which it is sold. Currently, the legislation specifies that only bottled water is GST free, making water in a 4-litre cask subject to tax. This is an absolutely extraordinary situation where, if the still water is in a bottle, no GST is applicable but, if the water is in a cask, it is subject to GST.
A second anomaly concerns unprocessed cow's milk. This is to be made subject to GST. On the other hand, processed milk will be GST free. This puts milk processors in a negative cash flow position, in the same way that meat processors are. This means that unprocessed cow's milk will be taxable but that other unprocessed animal milk, such as goat's milk, will be GST free. I point this out as simply yet another of the anomalies in the GST.
The third food issue which is being dealt with in the legislation is the fact that in order to obtain GST-free status for food the food 
 will now have to be for human consumption. So, for example, meat bought from a butcher to give to a dog would be taxable, even though that same food would be GST free if bought for human consumption. This is an extraordinary situation. We have the Treasurer intending to make meat bought from a butcher for the family dog subject to the GST when the same meat bought for human consumption will not be subject to the GST. I want to ask the Treasurer: is it now his intention that giving Fido scraps under the table will constitute tax avoidance? Is it now not the case that not only is the GST a dog's breakfast but that the dog's breakfast has become subject to the GST? I think it is an extraordinary state of affairs that, once again, demonstrates the anomalies we have found developing within the GST.
In terms of other major items in this bill, the small business cash accounting threshold is to be increased from $0.5 million to $1 million. This is consistent with the figure announced in the business tax review. The income tax treatment of GST is clarified—I use that term advisedly; much of this is very complex—to the extent that GST should not impact on the income tax liabilities for GST registered taxpayers. The original provisions were supposed to achieve this but are deficient in a number of technical ways.
There are a number of other significant areas of the legislation that I want to touch on briefly. One concerns powers being given to the ACCC to monitor prices going up before the introduction of the GST. In the original legislation the ACCC had no power to stop anticipatory price rises. This is naturally a matter of concern because, if you have the ACCC's powers with respect to goods and services not commencing until the GST implementation date of 1 July next year, it would be in the situation where it could not do anything about businesses unreasonably raising their prices in anticipation of the GST.
This draws to my mind an issue I have taken up with the ACCC concerning advertising in advance of the GST. In August  I happened to notice a sign in Brisbane at a Volvo car dealer's, Volvo Austral Motors, saying `Beat the GST'. Most people in this 
 House will be aware that not only are car prices not supposed to rise as a result of the GST; they are supposed to fall as a result of the GST—or at least as a result of the departure of wholesale sales tax. So it was my concern that that advertising might be misleading, deceptive and foul of the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Accordingly, I wrote to the ACCC drawing this issue to their attention.
They responded to me saying that they had discussed the issue of introduction of goods and services tax and that Volvo had responded that they had made a commercial decision to pass on savings resulting from the impending tax change to consumers prior to the introduction of the goods and services tax. So consumers who purchase a Volvo now rather than after 1 July 2000 will not be any worse off, as the price has already been reduced to reflect savings resulting from the tax change. That is all very well—and we all welcome Volvo's doing that—but that does not justify a sign saying `Beat the GST'. Words like `Beat the GST' imply that motor vehicle prices will rise after the GST comes in. It is not sufficient support for such a claim to be able to say that prices will not fall. So I certainly do not accept that the statement `Beat the GST' is an accurate one. I would still contend that it is misleading and, on that basis, I have pursued this issue further with Professor Fels and the ACCC. I hope that the ACCC uses the powers that are available to it and that are given to it in this legislation concerning anticipatory price rises to make sure that this is not an area which is abused. I know a lot of people have been expressing concern to me that prices have been going up in various places in anticipation of the GST, as some people seek to recover GST costs in advance.
The other area I mention in the remaining moments concerns claiming of credits for GST paid on insurance policies. This may emerge as a significant issue over time. The Insurance Council and the insurance industry have been subject to ACCC monitoring, and I know from discussions with the insurance industry that it has a great many concerns about how the government has approached 
 insurance policies and the calculation of their GST liability.
In conclusion, it is extraordinary that the government has to come into the House with some 454 amendments to its GST legislation. We hope rather than expect that this will be the end of it. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>A NEW TAX SYSTEM (INDIRECT TAX AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1999</title>

name: Vale, Danna, MP
text:
—This A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999  contains measures that will ensure that the new tax system will better serve the people of Australia. As well as minor policy and technical amendments, this bill makes a number of significant amendments concerning the fairer implementation of the GST. This bill is indicative that this government is listening to the community and interest groups and is prepared to implement measures to address various concerns when such concerns can fairly be accommodated in the overall reform program.
We are living in a time of rapid change, and our tax system must equip Australians for the coming decades, not simply respond to those that have passed. The new tax system will come into effect in July next year, and it has been designed to do just that. This historic reform was not simply an incremental change but a giant leap forward to catch up with the forces placed upon us by globalisation and to take a competitive Australia into the 21st century. The tax reform undertaken by this government was never for the faint-hearted but for those who have the courage to take on a challenge of major proportions. That probably explains why it was left to a coalition government to implement and why the opposition has fought this reform at every turn.
Inherent in every reform measure are considerable challenges, and a responsible government should allow a certain flexibility of response. I am pleased to see that our government has moved quickly to consider informed opinion and constructive suggestions that have come from industry and state government and has made adjustments to help smooth the path to the new system which will follow. For that reason, I anticipate that these amendments will receive a positive response 
 across the broader community. This will be especially so among small businesses, Australian exporters and primary producers, including the producers of grape wine and cider products and the providers of charitable residential accommodation.
The amendments do contain some bad news—bad news, that is, for any unscrupulous businessmen who undertake unreasonable price rises before 1 July 2000. This government is concerned that there be no opportunity for Australian families to be unfairly charged increased prices because of the introduction of the GST. One of these amendments will bring forward the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's price exploitation enforcement power. This will arm the ACCC and enable it to take immediate action against those who would seek to cheat their fellow Australians and use the tax change as a cover for a price rip-off or to make a quick dollar. This amendment is important if consumers across Australia are to have confidence in the impact of the introduction of the new tax system, and I am sure that it will gain support in the wider community. Certainly consumers in my electorate will appreciate in this amendment measures which will assist in the protection of their interests and which will implement these important measures as the government intended.
The amendments will also be well received by retailers who supply a mix of taxable and exempt food products. One of the amendments allows for the new special rules under which the Commissioner of Taxation will be able to determine alternative methods—such as retail schemes—of calculating the goods and services tax liability. This will reduce compliance costs for many small businesses. It will simplify accounting methods—which, again, will lead to reduced compliance costs. These measures will go a long way towards alleviating the concerns of some constituents who have had apprehensions about the compliance costs of the new tax system and their ability to absorb such costs.
Australian exports are vital to Australia's high standard of living and underpin our assurance that we will be able to maintain our high living standard and be able to continue 
 to deliver to our future generations. Our export potential underpins our confidence in our future ability to prevail as a successful nation. Another of the amendments in this bill will ensure that exports are GST free when ownership of goods passes to an overseas purchaser who is not registered or required to be registered before the goods are exported free on board. This amendment will be good news for Australian exporters, who must fight hard for a share of sales in a highly competitive international marketplace.
Other supporters of this bill will be the producers of grape wine and cider products. The amendments provide for greater clarity in the definition of wine products so that wine equalisation tax extends, as it was intended, to fruit or vegetable wines and grape wine products, such as wine cocktails, flavoured wines and Irish style cream drinks. These amendments will also ensure that private importations of wine are subject to the wine equalisation tax.
In the long and arduous debate that has led to the introduction of the new tax system, the government was often accused of heartless intentions with regard to charities and the people who depend on their services. Nothing could be further from the truth. Mindful of the concerns of many charitable organisations, the government established a charities consultative group to assist in clarifying the effect of the GST on the charity sector and to develop Taxation Office rulings well in advance of the introduction of the new tax system.
This government has listened to representations from the charities sector and in this amendment introduces the definition of non-commercial supplies of residential accommodation by charities. This will include supported accommodation and community housing. The market value and cost supply tests will be expanded for the non-commercial supplies of residential accommodation by charities from 50 per cent to 75 per cent. It will have the added benefit of reducing compliance costs while maintaining the principle that all commercial supplies should be subject to the goods and services tax.
This bill also clarifies what are assessable income and allowable deductions in certain circumstances. The goods and services tax received from customers when making taxable supplies will not be assessable income, but any decreasing adjustments arising under division 129 or 132 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act will be assessable income. Goods and services tax creditable as an input tax credit will not be deductible for income tax purposes. Any increasing adjustments arising under these divisions will be deductible to the extent the underlying activity is not of a private or domestic nature.
Currently, the legislation allows businesses to choose to claim an input tax credit on their business insurance premiums at the end of a quarterly or monthly tax period. These amendments will allow businesses the option to elect to claim the input tax credit at the time of registration or, subsequently, at the time of lodging the business activity statement. This legislation also provides that a full input tax credit is available provided a business's annual turnover of financial supplies does not exceed the $50,000 or five per cent rule. This amendment also intends to make it clear that in working out the value of the supply of a loan of money the principal amount of the loan is excluded.
There is some good news in this amendment for the constituents of my electorate, because these measures also allow GST-free status for first aid and lifesaving courses. In my electorate I have a significant number of lifesaving groups and people who are interested in resuscitation. I refer particularly to the Sutherland Shire resuscitation committee, which is conducting courses now, as the swimming season is upon us. This news means that section 195 of the goods and services tax act includes first aid or lifesaving courses as education courses. That section allows for such courses to be GST free under section 38-85.
However, under the legislation the GST-free status is currently limited to courses which provide training in lifesaving and resuscitation and which are provided by non-profit bodies. These restrictions exclude such activities as 
 lifesaving and education and training, lifesaving safety and aeromedical retrieval and rescue training from being provided on a GST basis. They also mean that courses in lifesaving and resuscitation offered by profit bodies are subject to GST. This approach is inconsistent with that taken more generally through the goods and services tax act where the focus is on the activity undertaken. Item 143 appeals the definition of the first aid or lifesaving course and substitutes a new definition which includes surf lifesaving and aeromedical rescue. Item 144 will bring profit bodies into the ambit of these entities able to offer first aid or lifesaving courses on a GST basis by omitting `non-profit' from the definition of first aid or lifesaving courses. That will be welcome news.
Not only has this government the vision and determination and commitment to tackle the huge task to modernise the Australian tax system but these amendments testify to a government that is prepared to listen and to consider the opinions and concerns of its constituents. These amendments also show that our government can tackle those concerns in a sensitive and flexible manner, acting quickly when justifiable reasons emerge for adjustments and finetuning. I am sure that many of these amendments will be welcomed by consumers in small business enterprises and other key groups within the Australian community, especially in my electorate of Hughes. I commend this bill to the House.

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
text:
—The A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999  contains 454 amendments. I have tallied up the amendments that have been made to date to the GST legislation. There are 302. In total, the streamlined new tax for the new century—here it is—contains 756 amendments, and this is the streamlined new tax for the new century!
