That the question be now put.
debate_title: <title>A NEW TAX SYSTEM (INDIRECT TAX AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1999</title>

name: Beazley, Kim, MP
text:
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aged Care. Isn't it a fact that section 63-2 of the Aged Care Act requires you to table in the parliament by 30 September a report which provides the following information: unmet demand for nursing home places; waiting times; accommodation bonds; building, upgrading and refurbishment of nursing homes; and the adequacy of Commonwealth subsidies? Has your department prepared this report? If so, why have you not tabled it? Have you got something to hide from older Australians, or is this just another example of incompetence in another portfolio area?
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order No. 144. The first part of that question asks for a legal opinion; the last part quite clearly is of a frivolous nature and does not seek an opinion. I ask that you rule the entire question out of order.
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: I put it to you that no question could be more quintessentially in order than the parliament asking a member of the executive whether she has complied with a piece of legislation for which she is responsible. It is quintessentially what question time is for, and it must be in order.
—As I am sure the Leader of the Opposition is aware from the eye contact I attempted to have with him, I deem the question to be in order but the latter part of it, in fact, to be unnecessarily provocative, and I think he was well aware of that. The question is in order, and I invite the Minister for Aged Care to respond.

name: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP
text:
—Thank you, Mr Speaker, but I do not mind a bit of provocation.
—The minister will respond to the question.
—Subject to checking whether or not the particular section referred to by the Leader of the Opposition is accurate—because I, like my other colleagues 
 here, would never take their word for it—I can say that there is a draft report which covers that sort of material which will be tabled in the parliament. I am sure that you will be looking forward to reading it.

name: Hollis, Colin, MP
text:
—Mr Speaker, I have a question for you. Are you aware that page 8409 was omitted from the proof copy of Hansard  on Monday, 11 October 1999? What steps have been taken to rectify this, and how often are members' speeches, especially if they are controversial, omitted from the copies of Hansard ?
—Yes, I am aware of this omission. Such was the nature of the member for Throsby's speech that I looked it up myself. May I be forgiven for observing that I wondered if there had been divine intervention in the absence of a couple of pages. But, all frivolity aside, I should indicate to the member for Throsby that this is an extraordinarily rare occurrence. In fact, what happened on the night in question when the proofs were being printed was that the two Docutech machines that the House uses for printing the proof Hansard  were running simultaneously. One of them was producing perfect copies and the other was producing copies in which the page referred to was missing.
As all members will be aware, the proof Hansard is available by about 9 a.m. When the absence of the speech referred to was noted, the printing office then re-ran the Hansards and made, I think, 150 copies of a reprinted edition available to all members and made 180 available around Australia to those various outlets that it was thought may have missed out.
Normally, if an error occurs, an erratum page is inserted or provided the next day. By reason of the fact that this was not merely an 
 error but a page missed altogether, a reprint was determined to be justified. I think it is fair to say that all that could reasonably be done to cover the error was done.

name: Macklin, Jenny, MP
text:
—What we have here is a cover-up of massive proportions, and we saw the Minister for Health and Aged Care continue this cover-up today in question time, slip-sliding away, not answering the questions at every turn. This minister for health started negotiations with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists in February 1998 to extend Medicare rebates to MRI machines. The Australian Health Technology Advisory Council had recommended—and this was the point the 
 Leader of the Opposition was making in question time—that the number of machines that existed in Australia back in 1998 in public and private locations was sufficient to meet Australia's needs. So the number of machines that we had back in February 1998 already operating in public hospitals and in the private sector were adequate to meet Australia's needs. This is a very important point in the policy debacle that is now before us. There was no need for any more machines to be brought into this country.
Some relocation of machines was needed and it is correct that there were some problems in regional Australia. AHTAC had recognised that. In fact, the government had recognised that some of these machines needed to be moved so that access would be improved for people in the country. But we now know today that this advice, originally provided by an independent body, the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee—an independent committee of the government—has been completely ignored.
The minister, in answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question today, once again tried to ignore that fact so that he is not hoist on this extraordinarily bad policy judgment. He tried to wriggle around and say that he did not ignore his department's advice, he did not ignore technical advice; that in fact he accepted the department's advice about a budget night cut-off for new contracts. But what he forgot to mention in his answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question is that the department's original advice, the department's original position, was to have geographic planned control over the numbers of MRI machines. The minister now is deliberately blurring these two pieces of departmental advice. The original advice was not appreciated by the College of Radiologists. They did not want to see the extension of Medicare rebates limited only to those machines currently in operation.
If I go to the minutes of the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists of 21 April 1998 that I tabled today, those minutes say that the doctor in question commented on the `negotiations'. Remember that was the other word we had a bit of stumbling over in 
 question time—`negotiations'. Who do we think they were negotiating with? Each other? They were negotiating with the government. He commented on the `negotiations leading to the consideration of a possible 18-month freeze on new sites' and `concerns which had been raised if MRI rebates were to be available initially only to existing sites'. So it is quite clear that the College of Radiologists had made it plain to the government that they did not like the department's preferred option, that they did not like AHTAC's original recommendation. The college go on to say that the task force—that is, the task force of the college—believes that `it is essential to get MRI onto the MBS schedule initially and then to make modifications over time'. What sort of health minister do we have who does not have any idea that these negotiations are going on?
 The minutes of 29 April of the College of Radiologists talk about `being scheduled to meet with the minister next week'. This is extraordinary, given the minister apparently did not let on about anything. Of course, he made the decision; it did not come from the College of Radiologists. It says:
. . . he was scheduled—
that is, the radiologist in question—
was scheduled to meet with the Minister next week if Council—
that is, the council of radiologists—
supported the MRI proposal developed by the MRI Task Force.
What the government was negotiating about was not AHTAC's original policy proposition, not the department's original policy proposition, but the policy proposition developed by the College of Radiologists. That is what was going to be discussed at the meeting held between the minister and the College of Radiologists.
I agree about one issue with the minister and the College of Radiologists which goes along with the original recommendation of AHTAC: there was a need for better access for all patients but, of course, there was no need for extra machines. The College of Radiologists say that the objectives of the task force were to increase funding for MRI, both 
 public and private, and that they wanted that done in a mainstream way by having a Medical Benefits Schedule item for private providers and an increase in grants for the public.
Then over on page 3 of the minutes of 29 April—this really goes to the point made by the Leader of the Opposition in question time—it says this:
Particular concerns were expressed about the Government's control of MRI supply.
So at this point we are still having concerns raised by the College of Radiologists about what the government's control measure might be. However, it goes on:
It was mentioned that, this being an election year, the Government has been generous—
past tense—
and it would be wise for the College to act quickly to advance this issue.
Of course it was not the case that the college had anything other than the MRI rebate in mind when they were talking about generosity. The minutes then said the college supported the MRI proposal and went on to say:
. . . the College cannot walk away as we will not have this opportunity again for some years.
Of course the `next years' not necessarily being election years. It then goes on—and this is very serious indeed: 
. . . Council . . . empowers the President and Chairman . . . to proceed with direct negotiations, with the understanding that Council would have input into the matter of supply control. In particular, Council has reservations about any proposal that control should be by site restriction.
These are very serious matters indeed. This was reiterated in their minutes of 4 May where they again raise concerns about a possible site freeze. So here we are just before the critical meeting, and the College of Radiologists are still raising their primary concern about a possible site freeze. The minutes state again:
.	 the time for negotiation is over, it is the best position the College will be able to achieve in the short to medium term.
These are very serious matters which show that in fact the government was negotiating for weeks ahead of the meeting that the minister has referred to in question time about this critical issue of supply control.
It is interesting to also look at the important message that was put out by the College of Radiologists the day after the budget. Once again we have reference to that critical report that was written by the Australian Health Technology Advisory Council. It says:
The AHTAC report has formed the basis for the college proposal and fellows—
that is, fellows of the college—
should note relevant aspects of the record of interview, including the current oversupply.
This is their recognising back in May the current oversupply that existed back then and the maldistribution of MRI capacity in the community. This is the piece of advice that radiologists did not take, because the president of the college went on to say:
I would strongly urge fellows to exercise caution with regard to their proposed involvement in any new MRI ventures.
Some obviously did not take the sensible advice that was put forward to them by the president of the college at the time.
These are very serious matters indeed that the minister refers to the Auditor-General today. Of course we had a bit of trouble getting the letter to the Auditor-General that set out the nature of the inquiry that this minister has instigated not at the earliest opportunity—not the first time that problems were raised with him. That is not when we had the first Auditor-General's report. But, of course, what else could we expect from this minister.
What is interesting is the nature of the letter that the minister has written to the Auditor-General, the nature of the reference. What you would expect in the nature of a reference to the Auditor-General is an outline of the problem that the minister is asking the Auditor-General to report on. Given that the minister will be one of the people that the Auditor-General will have to call to examine his involvement in this very messy and sordid affair, what do we see in this letter to the Auditor-General? We see the argument put forward by the minister to support his side of the case. He says:
While the negotiations were of a confidential nature, it was recognised that formal confidentiality agreements for the college's negotiators would be 
 inappropriate because of their need to consult the college membership more widely on aspects of the agreement.
That is a matter for the Auditor-General to investigate, not for the minister to put in argument in his first letter setting out the terms of reference for this essential inquiry. He goes on at the end of the first page to further justify his case:
This measure—
that is, the supply control measure—
was not discussed in the negotiations.
Once again, Minister, this is a matter for the Auditor-General to inquire into, not for you to put argument about when you are giving the Auditor-General a reference.
The piece de resistance comes at the end of the letter. He says to the Auditor-General:
As you would appreciate, there is a significant dilemma facing governments negotiating agreements such as the diagnostic imaging agreement with professional organisations. It is difficult to negotiate agreements around potentially commercially sensitive issues without revealing information that could be advantageous to some members of the group.
I read that as a confession. That confesses that what we have been putting to this minister for eight months is exactly what happened—that the information got out, people took advantage of it and they have taken this government and the taxpayers of Australia to the cleaners. Of course they had inside information. Otherwise why would they have gone out and invested $150 million of their own money? They put their own money up. Why did they put it up? Because they knew that, from the minister's own letter to the Auditor-General, the information they had received could be advantageous.
It was advantageous all right. It was extremely advantageous to a very large number of radiologists who have benefited to a very large degree as a result of this minister letting the cat out of the bag, making sure that the proper processes were not followed—the processes to make sure that the budget and the taxpayers were protected and that we did not have the outrageous scan scam that we are confronted with today.
This Auditor-General's report will be very useful when it is done, but we are still calling for a royal commission. That is the only way we are going to get to the bottom of this minister's involvement. It is the only way we can make sure that the public purse is protected because, for the last 15 months, he has been trying to cover up, to not answer questions and to make sure that this issue just goes away. It will not. (Time expired)

name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
text:
—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for the option to participate in this debate. The opposition makes a number of allegations, most of which we have gone over before and none of which have any substance, but I am happy to repeat and refute the allegations. I am pleased that the honourable member for Jagajaga is prepared to concede that the Auditor-General's report will be useful. I believe it will be. I have said that I am happy to cooperate in all ways with the Auditor-General.
I assume that, were I not to do that, he would comment unfavourably on that in his report. My department can be compelled to cooperate. I cannot be compelled, but I am more than willing to give an undertaking that I, my current staff and my former staff will give him all available assistance. I will also seek similar assistance from the College of Radiologists. The reason I am prepared to do that is very simple: the procedure that we followed on this was meticulously careful because we knew it was of a commercially sensitive nature.
Speaking generally, I am pleased the opposition has decided to move back from making allegations about people not in this House who are known to me. As one gets on in this job, one sees things repeat themselves. In the past, I have not found those sorts of allegations to ever benefit anyone. I think everybody loses from them. Because the two people involved are not able to defend themselves, I feel I should defend them.
Dr Best was mentioned yesterday as arranging dinners for me. It was implied that this had something to do with him being appointed to the National Health and Medical Re 
 search Council. It is true I appointed him to a subcommittee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, but so did the Labor Party. When Graham Richardson was health minister he did exactly the same thing. Graham Richardson appointed Dr Best to a subcommittee in 1994 for a period of three years, Dr Best carried out that job in a distinguished manner, and I reappointed him to the Strategic Research Development Committee.
Dr Best is not a radiologist. He does not have anything to do with MRI. He is a public health physician, which is about as far away from MRI as you can get. He did tell me that at one stage he did have something to do with MRI, and that was in negotiations with Neal Blewett, a former Labor Party minister. He has worked for state and federal Labor governments as well as working for state and federal Liberal governments. He is a past president of the Faculty of Public Health Physicians. He is a distinguished member of the medical profession. Before question time, Dr Best provided me with a letter that he has written to the Manager of Opposition Business. It says:
Dear Bob
I read with some surprise, bordering on disappointment, the question you directed to the Minister today concerning fundraising functions I am supposed to have organised. Let us get the record straight.
Over the past 15 years as a consultant I have worked for both Liberal and Labor Governments. I have never organised a fundraising function for Michael Wooldridge, whom I value as a friend.
Therefore the rest of your impugning my reputation behind the cloak of parliamentary privilege is irrelevant. If you were worth your salt you would at least have checked your facts.
I would therefore seek your public apology.
I table the letter. By way of explanation, I did say that I thought Dr Best had organised a dinner for me. Like most members of this place, I attend a very large number of dinners. They are a chore from time to time, but they are a part of parliamentary life. Over the last 6½ years, since I was Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I have attended literally hundreds of dinners with hundreds of people. I thought it was safe not to deny the allegation when I could not prove my position without any 
 warning but, on checking, Dr Best has never arranged a dinner for me.
The second person whose reputation was impugned was Dr Meikle. Dr Meikle is overseas, but he was previously in the Victorian Imaging Group. I had a letter today from the Victorian Imaging Group, which states:
Dr Meikle notes some matters of fact that may be relevant to the Minister's situation:
.	 Dr Ron Meikle ceased work practising as a Radiologist for the Victorian Imaging Group at the end of March 1998;
.	 Dr Ron Meikle has not acted on a Royal Australasian College of Radiologists Committee;
.	 The association with Dr Jack Best and Dr Ron Meikle in relation to a fund raising dinner may be related to Dr Best's involvement with the Howard Florey Foundation and a donation of $20,000 made by Medical Imaging Australasia/Victorian Imaging Group to the Howard Florey Foundation to assist in its promotion of medical science. Dr Best and Dr Meikle attended a fund raising dinner in Adelaide at which the Minister spoke.
That was a fundraising dinner for the Howard Florey Foundation, not for the Liberal Party. There were several hundred people in the audience. The letter continues:
Dr Meikle has no record of organising any fund raising dinners for the Minister.
That is true, because he has not. He has attended a dinner, he tells me. It was a Melbourne Cup Calcutta in 1995. I think I stung him for $100. So to impugn a person's reputation with no basis in fact at all is a very serious thing. I table that letter as well.
The shadow minister went on to talk about the Victorian Imaging Group. She seems to like talking about this group because I notice that she talked about it in a debate in parliament last week. Radiology is an area where there are a lot of intraprofessional rivalries. It is a rapidly changing profession and it contains a lot of very decent and honourable people, but it is also a profession where there is much jealousy. I suggest that whoever is feeding the shadow minister information she should ignore them in the future because the information that she is getting is simply not correct. She talked yesterday about the Victorian Imaging Group having an MRI at the 
 Monash Medical Centre. The MRI at the Monash Medical Centre is owned by the Monash Medical Centre itself. It is in a public hospital. It is not the Victorian Imaging Group's machine. The shadow minister chose to mention the Victorian Imaging Group in Hansard on 14 October 1999, saying:
I recently had cause to look at the web site of one of Victoria's larger radiology practices—the Victorian Imaging Group. The VIG boasts no fewer than 28 sites run by 250 staff under the supervision of 12 radiologists. How can the department honestly believe that, with its professional supervision rules, these are being met when 12 radiologists are split between 28 sites?
I agree that that would be pretty difficult. I checked today with the Victorian Imaging Group and, in fact, they have 23 radiologists—not 12, as she suggested—and this number has been stable over a long period of time, and they have only 18 sites at which they undertake ultrasound. So 23 radiologists are quite capable of providing supervision to 18 ultrasound sites.
I mention this not out of any point scoring but to make the point that at the moment lots of people in the radiology profession are running around with claims and counterclaims, some of them quite scurrilous and almost every one of them wrong. They are doing it because the profession has to come to grips with the fact that there is a significant minority within their profession that appear to have done the wrong thing. I am receiving letters from radiologists actually congratulating me for finally clamping down on some of the cowboys. The behaviour of some people in the profession has been quite unacceptable.
To answer the points of substance in the matter of public importance, the opposition makes much of the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee's report. I have a copy here dated October 1997. I am somehow supposed not to have followed their advice. I am puzzled by this because, for a start, on page 58 it mentions location of units and gives three general principles about location of units. The first principle `requires a sufficient population base'. This is correct. The second principle is:
. . . as MRI is only a portion of the specialist consultation and subsequent treatment, locating 
 MRI services in settings which ensure that there is a cluster of these key specialties is appropriate for both quality and efficiency reasons.
That we have done. It continues:
Thirdly, an MRI service should be located in radiological departments or practices which offer a comprehensive range of alternative imaging modalities and procedures, such as CT scanning, ultrasound, angiography and myelography.
We have done that too. So it is hard to see where we have not taken their advice. If we go to the final recommendations on page 69, they talk very little about location of machines and are very fuzzy, so there is no advice there that we could not have particularly taken.
The recommendations on the second dot point talk about the number of units, and again the shadow minister makes much of our oversupply. But that misses the point. We have not tried to reach a desired number of scans by limiting the machines; we have done it by limiting the scans themselves. If you have a look at our tax calculations, you will see around that time public hospitals were doing about 50,000 to 60,000 scans a year. They said that we needed another 40,000 to 48,000 scans a year—this is 1997—and then over the next five years we would need another 16,000 to 24,000 scans. In other words, we needed about 124,000 scans a year. In fact, that is just about spot-on what we have funded, with 408,000 scans over a three-year period, starting low and increasing because in the last few years the types of investigations where MRI has been proved to be useful have expanded. So, far from somehow taking or not taking the advice, what we ended up doing was completely consistent with the AHTAC report, a report that we have found very useful.
There is much about us apparently not following correct procedure here. That simply could not be further from the truth. One needs to understand the nature of this investigation. It is not what you might do, say, when you are reforming the tax policy—when you bring in some outside experts to have a look at what you have done to give you some practical advice on whether or not it will work. Both sides of the House when in government have done that. This was a formal negotiation 
 with a professional group. I remind honourable members that the government and the cabinet were aware of this. I was specifically authorised to carry out this negotiation with the College of Radiologists. This is something that is minuted in the cabinet minutes.
We were negotiating with them as a representative group. We expected them to consult their members and to tell us the views of their members. MRI was one small component of what we were doing. Essentially, we were negotiating a price and volume arrangement with radiology, and that needed the cooperation of the profession. It could not be done without the cooperation of the profession. A similar agreement had been negotiated with the Royal Australian College of Pathologists in 1996. It has contained the growth in pathology and enhanced the professional nature of the profession of pathology. It has worked so well that the college signed a second agreement earlier this year with the government.
Much has been made of this being a scam. I was actually the first to use the word, and I believe it is. If you look back in history, the last time this happened was under the Labor Party with pathology in the mid-1980s. Report 236 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into pathology was the thing that prompted pathology to change. Today pathology is a highly professional group, able to interact with government and run a proper three-year agreement. I hope that what has happened with MRI will prompt radiology to become equally professional and perhaps be the thing that makes people in that profession realise that negotiating with government can be done but needs to be done in good faith with certain probity around it.
There was nothing unexpected about us funding MRI. I have said in this House numerous times since February that there was a heavy lobbying campaign, and I had openly stated that I wanted to fund MRI. What was not known—and what was the market sensitive piece of information—was the nature of the supply control. The honourable member has provided minutes from the College of Radiologists. Again, given the internal turmoil in that body, I am not at all surprised that 
 minutes have come out. I am happy to look at them. If I have anything to add to an answer, I will. However, I point out that I have repeatedly been given the advice from my department as late as yesterday that the first time anything came to me about a supply-side measure was 5 May.
I believe the investigations we have launched will be completely thorough. The Health Insurance Commission has powers to compel, and I have tabled information from it today that suggests that it is likely to be sending 16 cases initially to the Director of Public Prosecutions—the result of a very thorough investigation. I am happy to look back and have the auditor look at what has happened. I have no reason to believe that there will be any difficulty there whatsoever. I am looking forward because we have to decide what to do with the supply controls at the end of 18 months. I have said that we will have a further investigation to get advice from experts there. I am happy to inform the House that Professor John Blandford, the head of the Health Services Management Development Unit at Adelaide's Flinders University, is going to chair this review. I have asked him to do this as quickly as possible. Professor Blandford was formerly a commissioner of the South Australian Health Commission. I am happy to table that information for honourable members. (Time expired)

name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
text:
—In his ministerial statement to the House on Monday, the Minister for Health and Aged Care finally came clean and admitted that there was indeed a scan scam. This happened after months of telling the House that there was no sudden rush for MRI contracts, clearly no insider knowledge and no improper negotiations with the minister. This minister is a real life Homer Simpson with hair. He even has the growl right. Every time he goes to the microphone, he comes out and says, `D'oh. I'm sorry. I think I may be wrong.' The minister stated to the House on Monday that, of the 111 machines notified to have been either in place or on order on 12 May 1998, 48 were ordered between 10 February—when negotiations with the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists commenced—and the 
 budget cut-off date of 12 May. What is worse is that 13 of these machines were ordered in the last two weeks before the budget.
The Labor Party has discovered these facts very slowly. It has taken us eight months to get the minister to reveal that 48 contracts were signed between February and May 1998. Before his speech on Monday, the minister steadfastly refused to reveal any of the dates of the contracts, arguing somewhat curiously that by revealing the dates he was endangering the HIC's investigation. Now, on the HIC's own advice, he has revealed that 48 of these contracts were made during that period.
If the minister were genuinely open and accountable, he would immediately reveal to this House the specific dates and details of the 48 contracts. More importantly, he would reveal whether any of these contracts involved members of the College of Radiologists' negotiating team that were participating in discussions with the minister from February on. We demand and expect nothing less. These simple pieces of information would assist us to answer the question of whether there was insider information. But this minister is not interested in getting to the truth about this incident; he is too busy ignoring the obvious and hoping it will all go away. This is a minister who has delusions of adequacy.
The accumulation of 62 MRI units around the country took 13 years, and yet in three months Australian radiologists suddenly ordered 48 machines at a cost to them of $150 million. They knew that some of that $150 million would come out of the pockets of ordinary taxpayers as a result of the changing policy made at that budget. That was an increase of 77 per cent in three months, yet this minister expects us to believe that there was not a fix on. For eight long months he argued that there was no fix and that the Labor Party simply did not understand health. We have had question after question but no answers—just growling from this minister across the chamber.
On Monday, however, the minister was forced to acknowledge a few facts. He finally admitted to the House that there was a $150 million scam played out on the Australian 
 taxpayer. He was forced to notify the House that the HIC was so suspicious of these contracts he would recommend to the Executive Council that a regulation be introduced to limit access to Medicare benefits to those machines already on order on 10 February, but not those ordered between February and May. The minister then explicitly stated:
This . . . will ensure that an advantage does not accrue to any person who may have taken advantage of backdating of a contract, a non-binding contract or any form of inside knowledge—
These are the minister's own words—
as a result of the negotiation process to order a machine before 12 May 1998.
His own words were `any form of inside knowledge'; that is where he has been got. Blind Freddy can see that there was inside knowledge. You cannot tell me that 52 radiologists around Australia committed contractual fraud and backdated their contracts after 12 May. Perhaps one or two did, but not all 52. That is why we need a royal commission to find out the facts. It is quite clear that the minister's answers are just not credible.
On Monday he admitted there was insider knowledge, but yesterday he backflipped and today again he decided it was all about backdating and non-binding contracts. Let us compare the minister's comments of the last three days with his previous comments on this issue. While we compare these comments, let us not forget that, several days before the budget in May 1998, the minister was warned by his own department that there may be a problem and that `we should address it'—that is, this problem—`ahead of time'.
That certainly has not occurred. Unfortunately for him, hoping major fraud will just disappear and the opposition will not notice is not his job. More unfortunate for him is that our shadow minister does know her job, and she has done it superbly. Let us not also forget that this whole scheme of MRI rebates is one of the minister's own devising. The original advice from both the department and the medical technologists was that the government should identify areas of need on a regional basis. So the minister has only himself to blame for the scam. Compare his confessions of the last three days to what he 
 stated in the months previously. On 11 February, he said:
I have no evidence, and no evidence has been presented to me or provided by the opposition, that there was actually a rush of orders in the weeks before the budget.
It was not a rush, Minister, but a stampede. On 10 February, he said:
. . . there has been no massive blow out in MRI numbers—
That is right, Minister, no massive blow out, just a 100 per cent increase in machines. Perhaps all the radiation from these excess machines is affecting old Homer's capacity to think straight. It is another case of, `D'oh, ordered too many machines, opened my mouth too early, forgot to take notes of important negotiations'—mistake after mistake after mistake.
The minister and his colleague Senator Herron also seem to have a bizarre belief that proper minute taking of meetings and asking for declarations of pecuniary interest is unusual government behaviour. He actually said in the parliament on 28 September, again in response to the shadow minister:
I have never told my department to keep minutes or not to keep minutes, and I didn't in this case.
The next day, he said:
It is not routine or normal to take minutes of every meeting.
It might not be routine in Kennett's Victoria, but it is routine in good government and accountable government. The fact that no minutes were taken but everyone was sworn to secrecy is another example of the minister's complicity in this scam.
If there was no passing of confidential information in that meeting, why were all the participants sworn to secrecy? What would be the point of that? Did the minister say, `Don't tell anyone what we said because I'm organising a surprise birthday party for little Johnny,' or is it more likely that the line was, `Don't tell anyone what we said because I shouldn't have said it'? I think the latter is more likely. Something happened in that room in May that was secret enough that people were sworn not to repeat the discussion, but heaven forbid that the public or the opposition should ever know what happened. That would be counter 
 to the principle of coalition accountability. The minister should learn from Jeff Kennett's mistakes, not try to emulate them.
The minister was forced, yet again, to back down when he realised that not only had his department not taken minutes but also not one of the members of the College of Radiologists had made declarations of interest. There they were negotiating with a professional organisation about Medicare rebates and it did not occur to the minister to maybe think that some of those people had a pecuniary interest, some of them may have had friends who had a pecuniary interest, in making these decisions. They were radiologists. That is their job. It is not surprising that this has occurred. Yet, when asked in the House about why they were not asked to declare any pecuniary interest, his answer then was:
If anything like that was to be declared, it should have been at the beginning of the process and not at the end.
Hear, hear, Minister! That is the whole point that we make. Dr Wooldridge's handling of this entire process demonstrates the problems coalition governments face. They simply do not understand public accountability. Remember the minister's call to Paul Harley-Green about public accountability where he called him `a rude, something else'—I am too demure to say—`nitwit loser'?
They understand about their mates and their mates' business interests, they understand about family trusts, but they do not understand public accountability. They are the handlers and keepers of the public purse. Their decisions have to be above and beyond any allegations of bias or mishandling. In government, they have to keep minutes, they have to ask for declarations of pecuniary interest and they have to stop thinking about money and political donations for one moment and start thinking about ethics. It is often too hard for them. This government is an organised hypocrisy.

name: Cameron, Ross, MP
text:
—My intention over the next 10 minutes is to do five things: to examine trends in service delivery and funding of diagnostics generally, to consider the model implemented by the Australian Labor Party for the delivery 
 of these services, to look at the impact of the October 1997 report of the Australian Health Technology Advisory Council, to consider the challenge which that presented to this government and this minister and to examine the allegation of some breach of probity on the part of the Minister for Health and Aged Care.
In relation to diagnostics, there is really a great story to tell, and the human story gets lost in the mud which is being slung from that side of the chamber to this. The key diagnostic tools available at the moment are X-ray, ultrasound, nuclear medicine, computerised axial tomography—or CAT—scans and MRI, magnetic resonance imaging. The improvements in diagnostic technologies have delivered absolutely outstanding benefits to Australian citizens and health care users.
We have gone from X-ray, which is just a single two-dimensional image, to nuclear medicine, which allows through the use of radioactive isotopes a much more precise diagnosis of problems, to CAT scanning, which allows us to build up a layered picture of a problem, to finally the Rolls-Royce of diagnostic imaging, the magnetic resonance image, which allows us to produce a three-dimensional, high definition image of a damaged piece of soft tissue. MRI has completely superseded older, more invasive, much more uncomfortable procedures for patients such as the myelogram, which required, for example, an injection of dye into the spinal chord and produced days and sometimes weeks of discomfort. All of that is now in the past, and it is no wonder that that created a huge amount of demand for the availability of the technology and a high pressure on the government to include it in the schedule of medical benefits.
The ALP's response, which was a fairly characteristic socialist response, was that the technology should only be available in public teaching hospitals, should only attract a benefit if you are in a public teaching hospital. The consequence of that for my constituents in Parramatta, whose only available local service was at the teaching hospital of Westmead, was to wait around in queues of up to five months, when many of them had a 
 potentially fatal illness which needed rapid diagnosis. But that was the Labor response. That is Labor's commitment to patient care—only have it available in a public teaching hospital and do not worry if the poor punters, the mums and dads and kids, have to wait in line for five months for a desperately needed piece of medical intelligence which should be more widely available.
It also had damaging consequences for rural and regional citizens in Australia who could not get to those 18 public teaching hospitals overwhelmingly concentrated in the capital cities. The alternative was to spend $400 to $800 to get the procedure available through some 40 private practices. So, again, if you are wealthy, under Labor's policy, you can get access to it, but the poor, the punters and the mums and dads have to wait in line for five months.
In October 1997, the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee, which is the technological source of advice to the Medical Health and Research Council, the principal advisory body to the Commonwealth government, produced a report addressing this problem which Labor policy had created. The critical thing here is the suggestion that this report is a secret piece of information which has been somehow secretly disseminated to a privileged few. This is a public document that has been on the public record since October 1997. Let me quote a couple of paragraphs from its contents:
The Commonwealth and state funding arrangements for MRI services have concentrated MRI units in tertiary hospitals. Such a policy inevitably restricts access for both doctors and patients. The resulting delay in diagnosis undoubtedly prolongs patient discomfort and/or uncertainty.
That was of course no great concern to the Australian Labor Party. It continues:
MRI may be a cost effective replacement for some conditions, but in the absence of adequate MRI supply another modality is used. MRI services should be located in settings where these key specialties are clustered. MRI services should be located in radiological departments or practices which offer a comprehensive range of alternative imaging. This would achieve economies of scale in staff and infrastructure, as well as providing the base for promoting cost-effective use of MRI via substitution.  

What we have seen the minister do, contrary to the suggestion of the shadow spokesperson, is exactly what the report has recommended. The key recommendation of that report is that there is a shortage of supply of MRI diagnostic services and that the supply needs to be increased. The report also stated that the concentration of MRI services in public teaching hospitals was causing damage to patients, to the quality of care and was leading to a misuse of scarce health resources, by reference to other modalities, because MRI was not widely enough available. The minister then set about coming up with an effective policy response to that set of problems and a process by which it could be implemented that would ensure appropriate health outcomes and observe necessary probity requirements.
We are talking here about a $1 billion industry. The idea that there is some simple solution to that set of policy and process challenges, that you could wake up one morning and just issue instructions, is fanciful and demonstrates the opposition's lack of recent government experience—and long may it remain so. The cost to the Commonwealth of diagnostic imaging generally rose by 330 per cent in 10 years. It rose from $279 million in 1984-85 to $1.06 billion in 1997-98. That 330 per cent increase is reflected in the recommendation by the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee that there had to be greater coordination and greater collaboration within the radiology fraternity to achieve better outcomes. Where there had been an instinctive reach for a CAT scan, for example—regardless of whether the treatment required it—in order to achieve certainty of diagnosis, that was causing a massive blow-out in funds. The minister had to ensure that that experience was not repeated with the MRI.
The idea that this could be achieved in isolation from a discussion with the Royal Australian College of Radiologists is, again, fanciful. The only way that a proper, important, necessary policy outcome could be achieved was to have a discussion with the people who were delivering the services. So rightly, properly and completely appropriately, 
 the minister authorised his department in February of last year to enter into what turned out to be a 10-week discussion on how the delivery of services could ensure that Australian people who need to access these services get it at a cost which is affordable to them and at the same time sustainable in terms of ongoing, Commonwealth budget outlays. That was the purpose of that 10-week discussion.
The minister rightly points out that there was an expectation in the market that the government would make a supply measure. That expectation was fuelled by the explicit recommendation of the government's own expert advisory body that, in the absence of adequate MRI supply, other modalities are used. Clearly, there was going to be a move to increase the allocation to MRI. The question was how that should best be achieved in a manner which did not involve some breach of probity requirements.
What then happened was that the minister, on the night of the budget, on 12 May last year, announced that there would be an allocation of funding, that there would be 400,000 images funded over the next three years but that you could only get a medical benefit for that funding if the machine was in service or subject to a binding legal contract on the night of the budget. That was the minister's chosen instrument to ensure there was not abuse and commercial opportunism on the part of the profession. As it turns out, it was an imperfect instrument. That may well be an outcome of the Auditor-General's inquiry.
It may be that we should have said that only machines that were in ships en route to Australia will attract the rebate. In that sense, it was an imperfect response but, nonetheless, it was, I think—and I think any reasonable person looking at it would also think so—a natural and practical response to ensure that there was not abuse of the benefit. Since that time, the government has received 52 claims for access to the benefit on the basis that those 52 machines satisfied the minister's budget night criteria.(Time expired)
—Order! The discussion has concluded.

name: Moylan, Judi, MP
text:
—On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 11th report of the committee for 1999 relating to the refurbishment of 4 Treasury Place, Melbourne.
Ordered that the report be printed.
—by leave—The report which I have just tabled concerns the proposed refurbishment of 4 Treasury Place in Melbourne. The building at 4 Treasury Place is a Commonwealth owned building located on the corner of Treasury Place and Lansdowne Street, Melbourne. It fronts the historic Treasury Gardens to the south and Fitzroy Gardens to the east. The building is part of Melbourne's Treasury Reserve Heritage Precinct which comprises a group of public buildings dating from 1858 which are of national significance in their own right. It was the first purpose-built federal building and was designed by the Commonwealth architect, John Smith Murdoch, who is publicly best known as the designer of the provisional Parliament House in Canberra.
The building at 4 Treasury Place was constructed in two stages between 1911 and 1913. Construction materials used in the building are also significant. It was one of the first reinforced concrete framed buildings constructed in Melbourne. It has brick walls finished with stucco externally and plaster internally. The original pitched rooves are clad with slate. The building is also notable for its association with the offices of the Prime Minister and the Governor-General, who have been occupants of the offices in the building since 1912. Accordingly, both because of its historic role during the early years of Federation and its location in the Treasury precinct, it is considered by heritage authorities to be one of the most significant heritage properties listed on the Register of the National Estate.
The building has been used continuously for ministerial and parliamentary office accommodation since 1913. It currently provides 
 offices and cabinet room accommodation for Victorian based federal parliamentary tenants. At present, there are six ministers and a parliamentary secretary accommodated in the building. There is also accommodation for visiting ministers, including the Prime Minister, the current Governor-General and two former Governors-General and some departmental staff.
The extent of the proposed refurbishment includes repair of the render work and application of new finishes, demolition of the non-original fourth floor additions, restoration of the slate roofs, replacement of all building services and refurbishment of amenities throughout the building. The aim of the refurbishment is to restore and protect this valuable heritage asset while providing the building tenants with an efficient and safe working environment with reduced building operational costs. The level of disruption associated with the proposed building works necessitates the relocation of tenants to alternative accommodation for the duration of the refurbishment works. The proposed refurbishment works are expected to take about 14 months and the official opening of the refurbished building will form an important part of the centenary of Federation celebrations in Melbourne early in the year 2001. When referred to the committee, the estimated cost of the proposed work was $15.8 million. During the committee's inquiry the cost estimate was increased by $2 million. The proposed refurbishment is now estimated to cost $17.8 million.
The committee's report recommends that the refurbishment should proceed and the committee has concluded that, whilst the building appears structurally sound, there is a need to refurbish the interior and exterior. Internally, the building's finishes and services are showing signs of disrepair and have reached the end of their economic life. Externally, the building requires extensive restoration, the removal of extensions, and roof repairs. The proposed internal and external works are extensive and can be justified to preserve the building and to provide office accommodation of a suitable standard. Occupation of the building during the refurbish 
 ment period is impractical, given the extensive nature of the work to be undertaken. Suitable temporary accommodation for existing tenants has been located at Casselden Place on the corner of Lonsdale and Spring streets. The cost of this accommodation is included in the project budget.
The proposal includes refurbishment of the basement, which contains the first Treasury vault. It is planned to lease the basement as a resource or interpretation centre. The committee noted the proposed design of emergency evacuation exits from the basement. The committee has concluded and recommended that the building certifiers have confirmed that emergency egress from the basement will be the subject of a dispensation from the Building Code of Australia. However, the committee believes that the provision for emergency evacuation of basement occupants should be accorded the highest priority and that the suitability of the basement as a public resource or interpretation centre should be investigated further. The views of the Melbourne metropolitan fire brigades should be sought before final plans are developed for the basement.
The internal refurbishment of the building services and systems will be extensive. The committee concluded that the scope and design of the building services and systems are appropriate for the operation of the building, subject to basement emergency evacuation requirements being satisfactorily addressed. The building is listed on the Register of the National Estate administered by the Australian Heritage Commission, which raised a number of concerns with the committee. The committee shares these concerns and has therefore requested that it be provided with continuing advice and information about ongoing discussions with the Department of Finance and Administration and the commission to ensure that all options are properly explored to maintain the heritage aspect of the building.
In conclusion, the recommendations in the report have been unanimously endorsed by the committee, except for the removal of a lovely stand of pine trees on the eastern side of the building. It would be my personal 
 preference to try to retain these trees as a very important link to the historical landscape design of the area, but I was a lonely voice on the committee on this. The reason given for the removal of these trees was the birds that nest in there. Of course, they foul the building.
It is a sad indictment on humanity today that we want to sanitise the world. We have kicked the roosters out of the backyard, and I heard the other day that some Queenslanders want to shoot the crows because they make too much noise. Now we want to evacuate the birds out of their nesting place at 4 Treasury Place. My preference would be to retain those trees as an important part of the historical landscape design. I commend the report to the House.

name: Hockey, Joe, MP
text:
—I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
The Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998  is part of the government's corporate law economic reform program. The objective of the program is to provide efficiency in the Australian economy, while facilitating market integrity and providing appropriate investor protection mechanisms.
The reforms contained in the bill mark a significant change in the regulation of fundraising, takeovers, accounting standards and directors' duties under the Corporations Law. The reforms modernise the regulation of business in Australia and will ensure that Australia's corporate laws meet the challenges of the present and future market in a forward thinking, responsible and innovative way. In addition, the reforms contained in the bill are integral to the government's broader objective of boosting Australia's international competitiveness and building Australia as a centre for global financial services. The reforms send a clear message to the business community that this government is serious about reform and 
 serious about making Australia a leading financial centre.
I am very pleased that the bill is now in its final stages of passing through this parliament. A number of amendments were made to the bill in the Senate. The government is a little disappointed that some of these amendments have been made, particularly in light of the extensive program of public consultation and discussion which was a hallmark of the development of these reforms. Nevertheless, the central reforms proposed by the bill are largely intact. Whilst the government would have preferred that the bill not be amended, it believes it is preferable to pass the bill as amended by the Senate rather than delay the implementation of these valuable reforms any further.
I will now turn to the details of the amendments. The Senate amendments include a number of amendments which address the recommendations of the report into the bill by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. These amendments will include the implementation of almost all of the recommendations of the majority report and a number of the recommendations contained in the supplementary report. The committee's recommendation that rollover relief from capital gains tax be provided in relation to turnovers and compulsory acquisition was not implemented. Instead, that recommendation is being dealt with in the context of the review of business taxation where it has been recommended that, subject to certain conditions, capital gains tax rollover relief should be allowed for scrip for scrip transactions allowing takeovers. The government has accepted that recommendation.
The government also took the opportunity to make additional amendments to the CLERP Bill in the Senate which will facilitate the effective operation of the Corporations and Securities Panel. The amendments are in keeping with the government's previously stated policy objectives of making the panel the primary forum for the speedy resolution of takeover disputes during the takeover bid period. For example, the amendments will introduce an internal appeal process within the panel. As the panel is to become the sole 
 forum for resolving takeover disputes, it is appropriate that an appeal process is available to any party who is not satisfied with a panel decision.
The amendments will also give the panel a rule making power, enabling it to make rules which would apply in addition to the takeover provisions. The rules will be subject to ministerial disallowance. The rules must not be inconsistent, obviously, with the Corporations Law or its regulations. The government also took the opportunity to make a number of minor technical amendments to the CLERP Bill in the Senate.
The bill was subject to a number of amendments by the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. I must say that I am disappointed at the Labor Party's continued opposition to the CLERP reforms which have, by and large, been very well received with almost unqualified support from the business and investor communities. On the other hand, the Democrats were very constructive in the discussions and in the debate. I reiterate my thanks to Senator Murray for his constructive role in this process.
The government's position has always been that the bill represented a balanced package of reforms. We were therefore very reluctant to see amendments to the bill without the benefit of consultation. However, we considered that the bill contains reforms which both the business and investor communities have been waiting for since the plan was first flagged in 1996. (Extension of time granted) Therefore, we accepted that it would be better to accept the bill in its amended fashion rather than pulling the bill totally.
The Democrats' reforms to the compulsory acquisition provisions will require the Australian Securities and Investments Commission to nominate experts to be used in valuing securities and will require a company to notify its shareholders when a person is reaching a position where they may become a 90 per cent holder capable of compulsorily acquiring the remaining securities. Whilst the government considers that these changes are unnecessary, it is pleased to see that compulsory acquisition reforms come to fruition, particularly in light of the very extensive consulta 
 tion process which accompanied the development of these provisions. Similarly, Democrat amendments to the sophisticated investor exemption in the fundraising provisions and to the accounting standards provisions while considered unnecessary by the government will not significantly alter the basic thrust of the reforms in these areas.
One final point I would emphasise is that the removal of the mandatory bid rule from the takeover provisions of the bill by the Democrats and the Labor Party is deeply disappointing. Neither the Democrats nor the Labor Party has been able to convince the government that the mandatory bid rule does not deliver significant benefits to investors and to the market as a whole. The mandatory bid rule would have provided an additional avenue for takeover activity in Australia. It was subject to a number of safeguards designed to ensure that all target companies shareholders had an opportunity to sell their shares at a fair price and to benefit from the control premium that a bidder places on the securities. The mandatory bid was to be an additional means of ensuring that Australia has a competitive market for corporate control. A competitive market for corporate control places pressure on managers of all corporations to perform at the highest standards, thus benefiting all shareholders. The government will be pursuing the implementation of the mandatory bid proposal, and I will be referring it to the parliamentary joint committee for further consideration.
Finally, this bill was the result of an extended period of consultation, and there are a number of people I would like to thank. Firstly, I would like to thank the Treasurer, Peter Costello, who set down in 1996 the guidelines for the development of the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program and who as shadow minister for corporate law had a significant hand in a lot of the policy issues and developments that are the background to this bill. This is as much his bill as anyone else's, and I commend him for it. Similarly, I commend Senator Ian Campbell in the other place for his vast amount of work in developing this bill. He conducted the consultations right around Australia. I congratulate him for 
 all his efforts and thank him for guiding this bill through the other place.
I would also like to thank the parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities and, in particular, Senator Grant Chapman, the chair of that committee. The committee took a very constructive approach to this bill. I would also like to thank the members of the Business Regulation Advisory Group, which is chaired by Catherine Walter and includes Peter Barnett, Leigh Hall, Rohan Jeffs, Jeffrey Lucy, John Murray, Robert Nottle, Malcolm Starr and my friend Les Taylor.
Similarly, I would like to thank the Treasury officers who have put in an extended amount of work in this area. Jim Murphy, with Senator Ian Campbell, travelled Australia on the consultations and, whilst no longer in Treasury, made a substantial contribution, as did Jennifer Wells, who has gone on to greener pastures after being my DLO for some period of time. I would like to thank the current unit—Michael Willcock, Veronique Ingram, Phillip Lynch, Emma Armson, Sandra Patch, Les Pascoe—and the other members of the Financial Markets Division and the Corporate Governance and Accounting Policy Division in Treasury. Finally, I would like to particularly thank Kersten Wijeywardena from my office, who has done an absolutely outstanding job during this very extensive and very draining debate. It gives me enormous pleasure to commend the amendments to the House.

name: Thomson, Kelvin, MP
text:
—The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, both yesterday in question time and again in introducing these amendments, accused the opposition of opposing the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 . Yesterday in question time he said:
It defies logic that the Labor Party would choose to oppose this bill and the principles behind it at every point. Every political bone in your body would make you wonder why the Labor Party would oppose it.
Frankly, he was misleading the House because the facts are that we did not oppose the second reading or the third reading here, we did not oppose the second reading or the third 
 reading in the Senate and we will not be opposing the bill going through now. So the minister has been regrettably misleading the parliament in relation to this.
We have moved amendments to this bill because it needs fixing. The bill does little for shareholders—in fact, it subverts the rights of shareholders, particularly minority and mum and dad shareholders. The opposition assessed this bill critically because that is our job. We moved amendments to it because it is skewed too much in favour of certain vested interests at the cost of many other people in this community. When we considered the bill, we considered a number of very important and critical questions: do the propositions encourage managers to be accountable to shareholders through consultation and disclosure in a timely manner? Do the propositions help define the role of the board of directors as active participants in the governance of the corporation? Do the propositions help define shareholders' rights and treat all shareholders of the same class equally?
Unfortunately, this bill fails to satisfy these questions. Yesterday in question time the minister wanted to quote the Australian Financial Review as saying that this was good stuff and that, if the government were serious about making Australia a global financial markets player, some of these things needed to happen. The minister was keen to quote the Australian Financial Review in relation to that; I do not know whether he was so keen to quote the Australian Financial Review when it reported how the minister was going with his idea of Australia becoming the region's chief financial centre. Hans van Leeuwen from the Australian Financial Review reported back on Friday, 8 October that the minister's strategy essentially involves Mr Hockey sitting down to a lot of lunches, dinners and boardroom meetings with multinational bankers. No-one denies, Minister, that you have been having the lunches, but we think spending money on lunches, dinners and boardroom meetings with multinational bankers is perhaps not the best way to spend the $7 million allocated in last May's federal budget.
This government has said that it wants to make Australia the biggest shareholder nation on earth, but it is not prepared to secure or protect the rights of mum and dad shareholders. Indeed, Telstra shareholders ought to be watchful of their company directors. This bill will make them immune from negligence liability. Telstra shareholders and other shareholders will have little recourse should company directors lose or mismanage their money.
The opposition at least succeeded in the Senate in correcting some aspects of this bill to allow some measure of accountability. But the issue of the directors' duties business judgment rule—about which we are very concerned—is nevertheless only one of a number of faults in this bill. Other issues of concern that the opposition has raised here and in the Senate concern the mandatory bid rule, compulsory acquisition and accounting standards.
So, yes, we have moved amendments to this bill. We do not apologise in the slightest for doing that. Our amendments have improved the overall balance of the bill, and the minister ought to be grateful instead of complaining about this. Despite what the government might have said about the opposition simply being contrary in relation to the bill, it should look again at how much of this bill we did support. We supported all of the fundraising provision, except for a one-line provision, we supported the whole proposal on the takeover panel, and there are many other provisions which we did not touch.
I turn specifically to the directors' duties business judgment rule. The bill includes a provision called the business judgment rule which would give company directors what is described as a safe harbour from negligence liability. This so-called initiative from the government is supposed to encourage directors to take more risks in their activities. (Extension of time granted) It will encourage directors to take more risks in their activities because external scrutiny will be restricted. It will encourage directors to be careless, reckless and deceitful, to the detriment of the company and its shareholders.
The government argues that there is currently a level of uncertainty in case law about directors' liability and responsibility, particularly in terms of their duty of care and diligence, that has constrained them from working to the best of their abilities. The opposition strongly disagrees. I think few could dispute the fact that court judgments have been fair and consistent. The courts have, in the main, exercised restraint. They have avoided second-guessing directors' decisions. I therefore believe the government's attempts in this regard will not add value and will not deliver clarity but rather will add complexity to the current arrangement. Moreover, far from clarifying matters, these proposals on directors' duties represent a Trojan Horse for watering down directors' standards of responsibility.
These proposals encourage directors to be careless, reckless and deceitful to the detriment of the company and its shareholders. They are totally irresponsible proposals designed purely to placate vested interests. The majority of Australian company directors would not benefit from these proposals. On the contrary, they will suffer. Those who would benefit are the directors who lack skills, are irresponsible or are dishonest. The government is sending the wrong message to directors and to the market. Shareholder interests and good corporate governance have been forgotten in the process.
The opposition is generally supportive of the principle of statutory derivative action, but the process put forward by the government is unclear and we expect that exercising statutory derivative action will remain confusing. We therefore believe that this provision should also be open to the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, ASIC, to take action on behalf of shareholders. Labor has moved such an amendment, but the government has not been prepared to accept it. Consequently, the statutory derivative action rule proposed by the government is likely to remain onerous for individual investors to utilise. It is doubtful whether many shareholders will be able to meet the onerous requirement of applying for leave from the court to take action.
I think it will be interesting to see, in the months and years ahead, whether shareholders or investors really do take advantage of the statutory derivative action in the way in which the government has put it forward or whether it becomes something of a dead letter. The ineligibility of ASIC from being able to apply for leave from the court is difficult for us to understand or support. As the government-created consumer protector, ASIC should surely have the power to act under these provisions. Labor accepts that it would be appropriate for the right to take a statutory derivative action to be extended to ASIC because small shareholders may not have the resources to take such action. The opposition's amendments are designed to ensure that this can occur.
While the government claims that its proposal to allow shareholders to take a statutory derivative action will balance the so-called safe harbour provisions, it is clear that its proposal does not balance the ledger at all. Labor's amendment will go some way towards achieving appropriate rights for shareholders. With the government trumpeting its support for Australia as a shareholding nation, I would have thought that it would have supported a regime that provides an appropriate level of protection for thousands of new and mostly, by definition, inexperienced shareholders who have entered the market. I think it is regrettable that the flip side of saying that you want to have a shareholding democracy—and the Prime Minister talks about us being the world's greatest share owning democracy—is that you need proper consumer protection measures. We are concerned that the government's proposals do not provide this and do not balance the ledger.
On the mandatory bid rule, which the minister made some reference to in his introduction, the provision to allow for easier takeovers by veiling the process from the wider market should not be there. We are pleased that the Senate has accepted Labor's amendments and that the government is now doing this as well. The tax concession on scrip for scrip takeovers is the solution that the government is really looking for, and we will have that. There is no need for the 
 mandatory bid rule as the cost to market transparency and integrity are too great. The opposition understands the arguments for the mandatory bid proposal, but we believe that the arguments against it clearly outweigh the arguments for it. We acknowledge that there are economic efficiency considerations or arguments for increasing takeover activity—or at least the threat or prospect of it—but it comes at a cost that is potentially more than the opposition is willing to risk. (Extension of time granted) Those costs will come from the subversion of good corporate governance principles such as transparency, accountability and equity.
No longer will there be an appropriate competitive regime for corporate control and, despite the proposed safeguards, shareholders will not get a better price than that obtained from an auction process. We move to omit the mandatory bid rule so as to ensure that transparency in the market is maintained. We moved our amendments because we strongly questioned the need for such a new rule. We believe that it would have led to significant disadvantages and few benefits. On the other hand, the government's position was one which would have given takeover bidders control of a target company before the market had been advised of the takeover bid. The government wished to encourage bidders to try to lock up key blocks of shares before launching their takeover bid. The result of such a proposal was that it could grant the bidder effective control of a target company before they had to reveal their intentions. That would give some takeover bidders a mechanism to discourage competitors emerging in the takeover process. Under such an arrangement, competitive bidders and directors of target companies would have less time to appropriately respond to takeover bids. Discovery of fair prices would also be restricted as there would no longer be an auction process.
The mandatory bid rule would go against the Eggleston principles—the principles on which the proposed takeover panel would consider and make judgment on takeover disputes. The Eggleston principles require that, first, shareholders of a takeover target 
 company know the identity of any person who proposes to acquire a substantial interest in the company; second, the target shareholders and directors have sufficient time to consider the offer; third, sufficient material is provided to them to make proper assessment of the offer; and, fourth, all shareholders have equal opportunity to participate in the benefits of the takeover offer. The mandatory bid rule breaks these principles.
The government is effectively sacrificing a great deal in terms of good corporate governance practices for potentially little gain in takeover activity. As I said before, the opposition is willing to support the capital gains tax concession on scrip for scrip takeovers. This, more than the mandatory bid rule, will raise takeover levels. If the new tax arrangement does not deliver, then we could reconsider our position on the mandatory bid rule. But the arguments being put forward on the mandatory bid rule simply do not wash with the opposition. We remain concerned that such a rule would lower the share price of takeover targets and simply allow takeover bidders to pay a lower price.
The government is proposing to extend the compulsory acquisition provisions to allow a 90 per cent majority shareholder in a company to compulsorily acquire the remaining 10 per cent share at any time. All that would be required is a notice of acquisition accompanied by an independent expert's report qualifying the value of the remaining securities. The government claims that the proposition is designed to remove so-called greenmailers, but this concern over greenmailers is dubious. Simply, this proposal is something that is about scrapping the rights of minority shareholders. Some people have even described it as allowing a legal means to expropriate another person's property. It is fascinating that the conservative side of politics are interested in this and are into expropriating property.
Mr Ted Rofe from the Australian Shareholders Association stated as much in a submission to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities. He stated: 
Compulsory acquisition involves the expropriation of the property of the shareholders whose shares are to be acquired. Minority shareholders in a partly-owned group of companies are in a particularly vulnerable position. It is therefore essential that any compulsory acquisition of their shares can be seen to be fair to both the majority and minority shareholders. As the courts have pointed out on a number of occasions, fairness in this context involves both fair dealing and a fair price. The proposed new compulsory acquisition power in its present form tips the scales too much in favour of the majority shareholders.
Since the government has been encouraging more and more mum and dad shareholders, it is indeed surprising that it is not making the appropriate efforts to ensure that the rights of shareholders, particularly minority shareholders, are protected. As more and more Australians become shareholders, change to compulsory acquisition becomes a significant concern.
A survey by the Australian Stock Exchange earlier this year estimated that 4.4 million Australians now hold shares directly. That is about 32 per cent of the population. The majority are likely to be inexperienced first-time shareholders who may not be able to best represent their own interests. (Extension of time granted) The government says that it wants to make Australia a nation of shareholders, but if mum and dad investors get in the way of the interests of big business then the government wants those mum and dad shareholders to move aside or be done over.
—Yes.
—Indeed. It is simply not good enough.
Mr Kerr interjecting—
—It is true. With little doubt, the extension of the compulsory acquisition rule was conceived and designed to placate vested interests. There is absolutely no need for it. I understand that the ASA is already receiving reports of shareholders being threatened that their shares will be expropriated as soon as this bill becomes law.
The CLERP Bill also seeks to revamp the takeover panel based on the UK model. While we are supportive of the principle that a body could act in arbitration to settle takeover disputes as an alternative to the courts, we 
 have some doubts about our ability to emulate the success of the UK's panel. Australia has a somewhat different business culture from that of Britain. Based on evidence provided to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, British corporations are less adversarial and less inclined to pursue litigation compared with their Australian counterparts. Because of these concerns, the opposition is supporting the government's amendments to its own bill on the takeover panel. We hope that these changes will boost the relevance and authority of the takeover panel in considering debates arising during a takeover process.
I turn now to fundraising.
