Fundraising provisions are among the more positive aspects of this bill and are primarily designed to reduce the costs involved with capital raising, especially by small and medium sized enterprises. To reduce the costs of capital raising, the government has targeted costs tied up with the preparation and lodging of prospectuses. The opposition is supportive of all but one of the proposals.
We agree, for instance, with a proposal that a disclosure document would not be required if a person made an unlimited number of personal offers of securities that resulted in securities being issued to 20 or fewer persons in a rolling one-year period with no more than $2 million being raised. However, it would be irresponsible for us to agree with a proposal which would allow licensed securities dealers to judge who would be defined as `sophisticated investors'—that is to say, investors not requiring access to prospectus or disclosure documents—and allow such investors to invest less than $500,000.
This provision is inconsistent with other criteria which define a sophisticated investor as having the appropriate resources to undertake their own investigation of a venture. We are opposed to the authority to be granted to licensed securities dealers because it may be abused, brought on by commission pressures. The Democrats and the government have allowed licensed securities dealers to declare a person a sophisticated investor and get them to sign a piece of paper to this effect. In those 
 circumstances, there would be no need to provide a prospectus.
If the licensed securities dealers define mum and dad investors as `sophisticated', they give up their rights to receive appropriate disclosure documents. People are arguing that sanctions would exist to deter licensed securities dealers from misbehaving. Such measures tend to address events after the fact. Once mum and dad investors lose their money, they usually lose it for good. We hope that the government sees merit in this argument and in the fact that there is a potential behavioural shift involved with the proposal. Entrepreneurs can now raise as much money as they wish through a licensed securities dealer, without having to issue a prospectus; therefore, expect an increase in capital raising through this process and an increase in the number of licensed securities dealers. This proposal completely undermines the current regime, which requires investors to be fully informed of any venture which they put money into.
Regarding accounting standards, the opposition is extremely disappointed that the government cannot comprehend the dangers of having the proposed Financial Reporting Council control the agenda of the Australian Accounting Standards Board. The bill gives powers to the Financial Reporting Council, FRC, to appoint the members of the Australian Accounting Standards Board and to approve its priorities, business plan, budget and staffing arrangements. These powers are about more than just oversighting the AASB activities. The FRC will effectively be running AASB.
With this bill the government demonstrates a lack of appreciation for the role that the AASB has played to date in ensuring that Australia has high standards of financial reporting and corporate disclosure which have engendered investor confidence and market integrity. (Extension of time granted) The opposition has endeavoured to move amendments to the bill to ensure that the AASB's independence is not compromised and that the FRC does not become just another layer of bureaucracy in the development of accounting 
 standards. Unfortunately, the government failed to accept the amendments.
We are concerned by the proposal to introduce formal cost benefit analysis by the AASB for every accounting standard proposed. There are difficulties involved with such a proposition for the standard setter in terms of the compliance costs as well as the technical aspects of determining the indirect costs and benefits to the wider community or economy of a proposed standard.
Furthermore, it does not give appropriate regard to the potential conflict that may arise from the fact that, while most of the costs involved with meeting accounting standards are shouldered by the preparers, significant benefits accrue to users and to the wider community. There is also a risk that this proposition would simply give businesses with purely short-term perspective some form of ammunition to discredit a standard when the longer term benefits may be quite significant. It is astounding that the government cannot acknowledge the dangers of this proposal and could not accept the opposition's amendment in this regard.
Tom Ravlic in the Age today addresses this very problem and quotes Mr Wayne Lonergan, the President of the Securities Institute of Australia. The article states:
. . . the failure to clarify the FRC's powers had the potential to jeopardise the integrity of Australia's capital market.
He said a proposed amendment pushed by the Federal Opposition would have ensured the board remained independent and the role of the FRC would have been to advise and monitor, rather than approve the AASB's agenda.
"The amendments proposed in particular by the Labor Party were in accordance with submissions made by leading industry bodies," Mr Lonergan said.
In conclusion, I am glad that the government saw value in Labor's redrafting of part of the accounting standards provisions, particularly that relating to international harmonisation. Australia should adopt only those accounting standards which have been extensively debated both domestically and internationally and which have demonstrated integrity. Australia should also play an active role in the development of accounting standards for worldwide 
 use. Labor has previously been—we have managed investments and other pieces of legislation—and continues to be supportive of sensible corporate law reform, and we will be continuing to support this legislation.

name: Hockey, Joe, MP
text:
—I do want to respond to some of the comments made by the shadow Assistant Treasurer. Firstly, he said that I had misled the House about the Labor Party's opposition to the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 . I did nothing of the sort. The fundamental point is that the Labor Party, in their true tradition and true to form, moved a raft of amendments which would have absolutely gutted the corporate law reform bill before the House.
It is an old trick of the Labor Party's. They opposed the GST package at the last election but, when the personal income tax cuts dealing with the GST came through the House, they did not vote against it, even though it was a package and it was being paid for out of the restructuring process associated with the GST. I do not accept the proposition put forward by the shadow Assistant Treasurer in relation to this matter.
Secondly, the shadow Assistant Treasurer made some comments to me about Australia as a global financial centre and said that it involved lots of lunches, dinners and various other things as part of the marketing. That was reported in an article written by Hans van Leeuwen in the Australian Financial Review on 8 October. I so happen to have a copy of a letter sent by a member of the parliamentary Labor Party to the Editor of the Australian Financial Review, who refused to print the letter. I propose to read out parts of the letter so as not to disclose who wrote it and then seek leave to table the letter, and I wonder how the shadow Assistant Treasurer will react. The letter begins:
Dear Sir
The only sensible points in Hans van Leeuwen's article . . . on the Australian and New South Wales bid to become a global financial centre were the remarks made by the Minister for Financial Services, Joe Hockey. 

Hans van Leeuwen's own comments were facile and stupid and in keeping with the undergraduate cynicism that mars much of what passes for journalism in this country.
Australia's bid to be a major financial centre is based on a good and improving set of fundamentals.
But there is little point in having a good product unless you get out and sell it, even if that does involve people like the Prime Minister, . . . Joe Hockey . . . "sitting down to a lot of lunches, dinners and boardroom meetings with multinational bankers".
He goes on to say:
Incidentally, where is this "continuing questioning of the Federal Government's regional financial centre strategy" that Mr van Leeuwen talks about. As far as I can see it's only coming from him.
It is no wonder that the Editor of the Australian Financial Review  did not want to print the letter. I remind the House that this letter was drafted by a member of the parliamentary Labor Party. I now seek leave to table the letter.
—Is leave granted?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. If the minister wishes to be malevolent and malicious, be it on his own head. He does not require leave.
—My understanding of the standing orders is that, apart from question time and when a ministerial statement is being made, leave in fact is required by a minister. So I repeat the question: is leave granted?
—If the minister seeks to pursue a malevolent course, we have means to prevent it. Of course we do not grant leave.
—Leave is not granted.
—I wait for the day when the Labor Party lets me table this letter and a few other letters that have fallen off the back of a truck in support of our ambitions to become a global financial centre. Isn't it funny that the Labor Party would not give me leave to table a letter from a member of the parliamentary Labor Party in support of what we are doing!

name: Thomson, Kelvin, MP
text:
—The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation knows that he can table that document if he wants to. That is fine. That is his prerogative. The more interesting issue arising from the minister's response to the Financial Review  article of 8 October, the very paper he was quoting from in question time yesterday, is: has the minister run-up the white flag on Australia's bid to be a regional financial centre? Clearly, suggesting that he wants to now share with Singapore seems to ordinary readers of the article to be an acceptance of defeat or some kind of surrender on the minister's part. We are entitled to find out from the minister what his real attitude is on this.
We are also very curious to know just how long it will be before we start seeing some return on the $7 million outlaid towards Australia's bid in this area and the minister justifying some of the expenditure that has been going on in this area. I also want to provide some support for the minister and, indeed, congratulate him on getting the bill this far. I feel I need to do this because no-one else in the parliament has. Senator Campbell, in summing up after the long and quite tortuous process of this legislation through the Senate, thanked the senators for their contribution and went on to say:
I did miss one person, however, that is Australia's Treasurer, Peter Costello . . . It was one of the great privileges of my life to work so closely with him during that two-year period.
We can see quite clearly the intent of Senator Campbell's congratulations for Treasurer Costello—that is, that one day, in a Costello government, he hopes Treasurer Costello will throw out that evil usurper, the present Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, and install Senator Campbell in his place. Then Senator Chapman, talking about the same thing—the CLERP program—places on record his appreciation for the work of Senator Gibson and Senator Campbell on this legislation. So we can see that everybody on the government side, but the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, has had a pat on the back. I do not want him to feel that he has been left out in relation to this matter so, on behalf of the opposition, I note his 
 efforts in getting this legislation through the parliament.

name: Hockey, Joe, MP
text:
—I thank the shadow assistant Treasurer for his magnanimous good wishes. In some cases, it is in keeping with his demeanour. He asked a little earlier to see some dividends of what we are doing. The dividends are clear. The Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank announced just a few days ago that it is going to increase its operations in Australia by 300 people. Deutsche Asset Management has announced that it is relocating all of its asset management activities for the Asia-Pacific region from the headquarters in Tokyo to Sydney, and, obviously, I declare an interest in that.
A number of others—including Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley—have also indicated that they are significantly expanding operations in Australia. The global links between our exchanges and the exchanges of other nations, including the MOU that I witnessed the signing of in Thailand between the Thai stock exchange and the Australian stock exchange, are part of the partnership arrangement that will deliver us better opportunities in the region.
The non-Japan Asia part of the world economy has enormous potential; probably half the people in the world live in non-Japan Asia. However, it represents only a small fraction, about 12 per cent, of the global economy and global market. It has tremendous growth potential. That is why we talk about partnerships in the region. There will effectively be four time zone centres in the world—the Americas, Europe, Japan and non-Japan Asia. We aim to be a major financial centre for the globe in non-Japan Asia. That is our window of opportunity.
We have skills that others cannot provide, particularly in back office operations. We can provide, from Australia, the IT support, the accounting support and the telecommunications for the entire Asia-Pacific region. We have excellent people, and that is reflected in the example of Merrill Lynch. They have 1,000 employees in Australia, of which only 
 18 are ex-pats. They have a further 250 Australians in significant management positions around the world. It is of great credit to Australia and its people that we have this enormous talent. That is having a global impact but we do not appreciate it here. What we want is for them to get into leadership positions around the world and to bring some of that wealth back home to Australia. That is what this push is about. Each step of the way delivers jobs and investment for everyday Australians. We have the opportunity to be a very wealthy nation. We want the regional pie to grow, and that is very important.
On that basis, I have no qualms about advising the House of the success. In fact, if the shadow assistant Treasurer has a look at yesterday's Hansard from the New South Wales parliament he will see that it was the Treasurer of New South Wales who was congratulating me on my performance. But I am humble and I will not go into the details of that. I will leave that up to the shadow assistant Treasurer. Given that he is prepared to blow my bugle, I will give him the opportunity to continue to do that.
Obviously the  Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998  is a key part of our development as a global financial centre. It is world-class regulatory reform. In fact, in my discussions with the monetary authority of Singapore, the program was referred to as `leading'. They anxiously await CLERP 6. We are going to give it. The best form of flattery for us is the fact that others are copying what we are doing. Unfortunately, the Labor Party is taking a different approach.

name: Sercombe, Bob,MP
text:
—The last few years in the Asia-Pacific region have indicated one thing about Australia's comparative strengths with the region, and that has been the comparative integrity and transparency of our markets. In terms of achieving the objective that the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation is on about relating to Australia's developing its capacities in financial services, one of the crucial things that has underpinned the Labor Party's approach on these issues before the parliament under the badge of CLERP—it is a rebadging of the former government's 
 corporate law simplification program—is in fact that question of market integrity and transparency. That is what has principally motivated the sorts of concerns that the Corporations and Securities Committee have put before the parliament.
For the minister to suggest that in some way we have been dragging the chain is playing pretty fast and loose with the facts. This minister is particularly sensitive about a few things. Long lunches is obviously one of them. The facts are that if the minister had not been on so many long lunches this legislation may well have passed through the parliament somewhat quicker than has been the case. This has dragged along for three years now under this government. That is not satisfactory.
The other area where the minister has been playing pretty fast and loose is the view he expressed earlier, that is, that in some way there is almost unanimous support for the government's position on a number of these measures from the business and investor community. I once again quote the very well respected chairman of the Australian Shareholders Association, Ted Rofe, in respect of compulsory acquisition. He says that compulsory acquisition involves the expropriation of property. This was quoted extensively by the shadow Assistant Treasurer, but to suggest that there is a unanimous view in the business community on the approach the government has taken is factually incorrect. There are a range of areas where there has been very serious concern in the business and investment community about that approach. Some of the aspects have been tidied up in the Senate but not all, and I do not intend to go through all of them. But for the minister to make these suggestions is misinforming the House.
The government, with respect to its approach to takeovers, seems to have the view that takeovers are always good. I would suggest that there are an awful lot of shareholders in a number of companies, most notably in recent times the AMP-GIO fiasco, who would dispute that view. What is required is a balanced set of corporate law measures that attempt to balance the interests 
 and protect all sorts of interests, not just the big end of town.
If one looks at the rhetoric of the minister when he expresses great disappointment about some of the matters he has before the House at the moment, it is somewhat disappointing that the government still has not learnt the lessons that these balances are necessary. That, I think, bodes ill for the future of some areas of corporate law, which, to come back to my starting point, is absolutely critical in maintaining the strengths and integrity of the Australian financial markets given the sorts of objectives the government has set for this country in terms of international finance. I was inspired to rise to my feet by the minister's misleading the House in relation to the attitudes of both the opposition and also of the business and investment community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Kerr, Duncan, MP
text:
—At the conclusion of this address on the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 , the opposition will be moving a second reading amendment which will foreshadow certain areas of concern which we had hoped would be taken up in this House through reference to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, but we understand that, in relation to the government's position, they are disinclined to that course. We will subsequently be pursuing the issues we raise by way of specific concern in the second reading amendment by seeking the cooperation of non-government parties in the Senate to have an examination of those issues in that place.
The government has stated two main aims in introducing this bill: to provide flexibility in Australian Federal Police employment consistent with the AFP reform program and to recast and to clarify the commissioner's 
 power of command. The bill alters the statutory employment framework so that there can be a greater reliance on industrial agreements—that is, it facilitates the removal of statutory fixed term appointments. The government has also attempted to introduce a regime which separates the commissioner's general employment and disciplinary powers. The commissioner will have a general power of employment, with most employment conditions being determined under the Workplace Relations Act. The commissioner will, however, also retain command powers as set out by the Federal Court in Anderson and Sullivan which will be excluded from the Workplace Relations Act. In addition to arrangements which currently operate by way of agreement with the Australian Federal Police Association on a voluntary basis, the bill includes provision for compulsory drug testing. The bill also removes the statutory entitlement to the Australian Federal Police Adjustment Scheme, which is commonly called AFPAS.
I should make a couple of general introductory remarks. Firstly, it was the Australian Labor Party which started a significant reform process within the Australian Federal Police. That reform program has not proceeded smoothly and has been the subject of significant difficulties with respect to the way in which this government has managed its relationship with the Australian Federal Police. The government in the past has decimated the Australian Federal Police regarding funding and support, and it is only now vainly beginning to try to fix the damage it has done.
If I might be specific in relation to recent events, the $155 million funding package for the Australian Federal Police announced by Senator Vanstone on 20 September was an example of the government's fudging of figures to hide the fact that they have not been, and still are not now, adequately funding the Australian Federal Police. I will examine the rationale for that statement, but I make the statement now that, of the $155 million referred to, only $5 million will, in practice, be new money to be spent by the AFP in an attempt to redress problems with 
 resourcing, funding and carrying out their core functions. Those are problems which have been caused by the government's fierce slashing of the AFP's budget in the past.
The reason I say the $155 million funding package really reduces, on analysis, to $5 million is that there is approximately $100 million that the Australian Federal Police's AFPAS scheme—which is being terminated by this legislation—has in liabilities that will now have to be paid out, most of them within the next 12 months, to officers whose 10-year contracts expire and, in some circumstances, to officers who stay in the force under the new certified agreements provisions and the provisions of this bill.
 Last year, the government also announced $115 million of funding following the Ayers report, but $50 million of that was to come from savings within the Australian Federal Police. The government has not given any guarantees that these savings were found. In fact, information which has been provided to me from within the organisation and the AFPA suggests that those savings were not achieved—which means that in fact $50 million of this year's $155 million will have to be siphoned off to cover that shortfall.
There may have already been some minor savings; but broadly, if you take the $155 million—of which much was made in terms of an assertion that there was increased resourcing for the Australian Federal Police—you have to subtract from that about $100 million for the AFPAS liabilities and about $50 million for the savings which were foreshadowed in the Ayers report but which were not achieved and which will need to be backfilled by that measure. So you actually come up with a very slight amount: in the order of $5 million of new money.
The government is continuing to fund the Australian Federal Police in an ad hoc, ineffective and inefficient way. I regret that the government has not yet released—and appears absolutely determined not to release—the Ayers report, so that there can be public debate about our prime enforcement agency.
One of the issues which we will take up subsequently and which we will be addressing in the amendments in detail is the advantage 
 that would accrue were this parliament to have greater oversight of the whole area of law enforcement. Currently, this parliament only examines the operations and workings of the National Crime Authority. We conceive that there would be great advantage in having a parliamentary committee charged with much larger responsibilities of looking at law enforcement in general, which would bring within its remit the Australian Federal Police and would also go to long-term strategic planning issues; the proper resourcing of the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority and other associated agencies; the way they work together; and the challenges and threats they face in the future. This government is operating in a piecemeal and quite covert manner in relation to a whole range of issues that really need to have proper public examination and the proper scrutiny of this parliament.
Today, in the Senate, the minister for justice made much of some remarks—at which I am sure the Commissioner now squirms when he hears them repeated—of the Commissioner when he unfortunately was taped in a radio interview. I attended the 20th birthday party for the Australian Federal Police, and was delighted to be there; and I do have enormous respect for those who occupy high office in the Australian Federal Police—the Commissioner, the Deputy Commissioner and those who serve right throughout the ranks—because I believe it is an organisation which, under very trying circumstances, has offered a high level of proficiency, admittedly with some difficulties and, I am certain, with a number of errors from time to time. Nonetheless I say that the Commissioner must squirm now, because I thought that the Commissioner suffered from an outburst of enthusiasm of a most uncharacteristic kind when he said in the radio interview that the current government had provided the greatest resources and the best support of any government in relation to the workings of the AFP.
I am sure that the Commissioner expressed this hyperbole in response to being pressed in relation to issues that were being put to him at that time, suggesting that the AFP's morale 
 was running down and that it was subject to considerable difficulties. Also probably at the back of his mind was the then pending motion of no confidence that was being brought against him by the Australian Federal Police Association, which went to the then negotiations about the workplace relations agreement that was being proposed and, of course, to the larger issue of the resources of the Australian Federal Police.
—Some of whom are in East Timor.
—The former Deputy Prime Minister makes that point. Might I say that I have indicated that the opposition, through me as spokesperson for justice, has continually honoured the service of the Australian Federal Police, and nothing that I say is intended to dishonour that. The record of service that has been given overseas in places like Cambodia and Haiti, and that is still being given in the Republic of Cyprus and most recently in East Timor is a distinguished one and will continue to be so.
I was trying to put the Commissioner's remarks, which I regard as hyperbole, into some context and to indicate why I am sure when he looks at himself in the mirror he must say, `How did I get myself to say those things?' If you go to the actual formal reports of the Commissioner, as presented to this parliament in the Australian Federal Police's annual reports, a very different story emerges. I might take the parliament first to the annual report of 1997-98, where the Commissioner referred to the previous report of 1996-97, in which he indicated he had identified a number of factors which had hindered the Australian Federal Police's capacity to perform its core functions. He indicated that those factors included resource constraints, high attrition rates and a declining capacity to accept referrals for investigations from other agencies.
He indicated that in that year—1997-98—these factors continued to exert pressure on the Australian Federal Police along with the continuation of savings measures introduced in 1996-97. These measures included restricted recruitment, across-the-board application of internal budget cuts, targeted reduction of 
 travel expenditure, limited filling of vacant positions and limited assessment of service levels to client departments. The number of fraud investigations initiated by the AFP continued to decline during the year and the gross attrition rate of staffing levels remained high at 7.41 per cent. He pointed out that the AFP experienced a significant reduction in base funding in 1997-98 as a result of the continued application of the efficiency dividend and a four  per cent portfolio base cut and reductions for whole of government telecommunications savings. He indicated that the  impact of reductions in base funding was exacerbated by a need to repay significant forward borrowings which had accumulated over a number of years. He mentioned a number of specific purpose allocations which had been given but indicated that they did nothing to address or relieve the underlying structural budgetary problem which threatened continued operational effectiveness and viability. That is an extraordinary thing for the commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to say in a report to this parliament. The nation's premier law enforcement agency in 1997-98 is reporting that its continued operational effectiveness and viability have been threatened by this government.
Then we turn to the current annual report. It noted that gross attrition rates to June 1999 were 6.58 per cent, down from 7.4 per cent in the last financial year, but it pointed out that this represented a loss of 173 personnel—112 police members and 61 staff members—while the reprofiling program accounted for the loss of another 57 personnel—49 police members and eight staff members. The report pointed out the difficulties in the rate of progress of some aspects of the AFP's reform program, particularly the implementation of certain human resource reforms, which are always going to be difficult. The report indicated that there remained problems—that, although there were some issues which had been relieved to some extent by funding that had addressed some of those specifics, there were still ongoing difficulties with the management and funding in relation to the organisation.
We have just tabled—I think today, but I am not certain; I would not be held to that— 
 the Commonwealth Ombudsman annual report, which points to significant problems in the internal operation of the recruitment program of the Australian Federal Police. The Ombudsman's investigation had found that AFP recruitment processes in the term of this government had lacked professionalism and raised serious questions as to whether there was a conflict of interest and/or undue favouritism in the process.
So I am certain that there is not much support in the Australian Federal Police or in the Australian Federal Police Association for the extraordinary comments of the commissioner. I am certain the commissioner looks back on them with some regret as he finds that they are being used and touted by the Minister for Justice and Customs—saying that all is well in the best of all possible worlds in relation to the funding arrangements that this government has put in place and the management regime that currently exists. Frankly, we do not believe it. The Australian Federal Police who are serving do not believe it. The Australian Federal Police Association is actively committed to the contrary proposition. And we are advised—although the details are difficult to nail down—that there continues to be a reduction in the number of referrals that can be accepted by the Australian Federal Police for investigation, whilst at the same time the number of referrals coming forward that require investigation is actually increasing.
This is not to denigrate the work of the Australian Federal Police but rather to put this debate and these reforms in a practical context and to get away from the braying self-congratulation that the minister for justice substitutes for analysis. In general, both the Australian Federal Police Association and the opposition support the general direction of this bill. We have consulted with the AFPA. The bill substantially redefines AFP industrial relations arrangements, but there are a number of questions that remain to be settled. It is not immediately clear how the new scheme will operate in practice—and the association and the opposition have concerns about several aspects of the bill, which are iterated in the second reading amendment. For example, the 
 wholesale repeal of the existing part 5 of the act which contains provisions relating to maternity leave, promotions, the operation of the Merit Protection Act and standards and rights with respect to employees seconded as officials of the union  are all issues that overlap with the government's approach to industrial relations and employment security.
Some of those concerns are not just restricted to the  Australian Federal Police, but we are anxious—in this environment where we expect quite a deal of those wearing the uniform or not wearing the uniform but who are agents of the Commonwealth in this important area of Commonwealth responsibility—about the trend of leaving crucial employment provisions and guarantees to the enterprise bargaining process. The removal of legislative provisions relating to maternity leave is particularly concerning for women and particularly concerning for those who, over recent years, have been making a significant contribution to the service and workings of the Australian Federal Police. It is not so long ago that it was a rarity to find a woman entering the Australian Federal Police, and we are concerned that the government has steadily eroded many of the legislative and social safeguards for working women which should be a fundamental part of our society.
Having had discussions with the Australian Federal Police Association, we expressed concern about what is believed to be lack of accountability and transparent promotional and advancement systems dealt with under regulations and industrial agreements which relate to existing provisions in part V of the act which are not provided for in this bill; the provisions which allow for dismissal following conviction for an offence which only receives a section 19B Crimes Act bond. The provisions in this bill anticipate that anybody so convicted of an indictable offence will automatically be dismissed from the force, but section 19B provisions apply only to convictions where a bond has been given, and that can only occur where an offence has been held by a judge to be of a trivial nature.
Notwithstanding the fact that the offence notionally is one of some seriousness and we would normally expect dismissal to follow, 
 section 19B can only come into effect where the judicial determination is that in fact what has occurred, whilst notionally falling within the terms of indictable offence, is in fact trivial. It may well be that that matter needs examination. It is one of the issues that we will be asking to be looked at whenever this matter does have a committee examination.
We also think there needs to be some examination of the process that the merits review of decisions of the commissioners will operate. I think that there does need to be some clarity about the relationship between the command and employment powers of the commissioner and the application of the Workplace Relations Act. It is clear that those two streams will overlap from time to time, and the working through of those issues and exactly how they will work in practice does need clarification. Perhaps some undertakings from the minister in the consideration in detail stage may assist.
The opposition is content for the measures in relation to compulsory drug testing to proceed, but we understand from the minister's office that she is content to give assurances that the process will continue in practice as it has under the voluntary scheme—in other words, that the arrangements which operate when somebody is discerned to have at some stage taken an illicit drug will remain as they currently stand. I think that is a matter that can be dealt with simply by the minister giving the undertaking that her officers have indicated that she is content to give.
Closer scrutiny of this bill is warranted. I might say that a lot of the concern that is being expressed in the second reading amendment and by the association might not have had to have come before this place had the government been more open in the way it went about the development of this legislation. When Labor was in office, we always regarded significant change to the legislation governing the Australian Federal Police as requiring at a very early stage the engagement of representatives of those who were employed within the Australian Federal Police and their association. That has not occurred in the development of this legislation.
Notwithstanding that, broadly, both the opposition and the AFPA are not inclined to throw the baby out with the bathwater; we think that they are, in the main, quite reasonable provisions. But, when you get down to these matters of detail, many of them—which perhaps could have been worked through and concerns alleviated by up-front and transparent discussion at an early stage—which do now need to be the subject of an examination in committee, could have been avoided had the government been minded to follow a less closed process.
The issues regarding accountability of the organisation are also important. The restructuring of the Australian Federal Police which is proposed by the bill raises issues of organisational accountability. Commonwealth law enforcement generally needs improved provisions to ensure that the community has a clear understanding of law enforcement's role. We need to be satisfied that there are properly developed and integrated strategic and tactical directions being adopted. After all, the Australian Federal Police, by a very significant order of magnitude, is the largest law enforcement body of the Commonwealth. There are a number of other agencies which have functions in the law enforcement area, but none have the significance and importance for the whole of government that the Australian Federal Police has. The organisation has always been regarded as the pre-eminent law enforcement agency of the national government.
It is odd, therefore, in that context, that the parliament has a scrutiny and oversight committee which examines the National Crime Authority and a scrutiny and oversight committee which examines the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation but none which examines the whole issue of law enforcement. Of course, it is not appropriate to bundle ASIO in with law enforcement generally; I am not proposing that.
However, the measures that we are proposing, and which we will be moving in the consideration in detail stage of this legislation, are directed towards giving this parliament the capacity to have a continuing relationship with the direction and the objectives of law 
 enforcement, so that we do not address these issues in a piecemeal way, so we can look at the whole range of strategic threats that we face as a community in the future—from organised crime and new technologies as they emerge, which open up new vulnerabilities, to all of those issues that come before this parliament—and so we can look at the organisational structures to best deal with them.
We can look at the coordination that needs to exist between the different agencies which have some carriage of different parts of the Commonwealth law enforcement brief—of course, they include a whole range of different agencies including, for example, the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, AUSTRAC and a number of other agencies which do have specific responsibilities—to make sure that the whole package fits together and works well. It is something that this parliament would be very much empowered by. It would give this parliament a significantly greater capacity to be able to look at strategic and non-operational issues which go into the whole law enforcement agenda.
In that regard I think there are very few who have served on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority who have not welcomed the insights that that has provided in relation to that organisation. I see it as being very positive for the Australian Federal Police were the government to adopt these provisions. I might also say that I have had discussions with the Australian Federal Police Association about these proposals. They welcome them. They think it is very important for this parliament to have a proper committee in which the larger issues relating to law enforcement can be discussed, often in private, often outside the partisan debate that currently passes for analysis and serious discussion of law enforcement, and away from some of the rhetoric that clouds the air. This is one of the particular measures which we will be commending to the government.
When this matter comes before the Senate we will be asking the Democrats and the other non-government parties—the Greens and Independent Senator Harradine—to support reference of the matters on which we have 
 expressed concern. These are concerns which have been raised by members of the Australian Federal Police. It may be that on some of these issues we need not proceed with specific amendments; undertakings that satisfy those concerns perhaps can be given. Other particulars may require specific amendments to be moved after consideration of those concerns to ensure they are legitimate and, if they are legitimate, you would expect the opposition—and, indeed, perhaps the government—to take the initiative on those particular matters. I conclude this overview of our approach to this legislation.
I was pleased with the briefing I received from the minister's office on this. Certainly since the bill has been published I can but commend the cooperation. I only regret that, in common with much of the way in which this government deals with law enforcement, there is often—as with the duck—tranquillity on the surface and much action underneath which the government does not disclose. That does not lead to good decision making in the end because there are interested parties who need to have their concerns addressed, not least the opposition. At some stage we will be back in government and there are important and longstanding issues of common concern that go to having a good framework for law enforcement. The Australian Federal Police Association, civil liberties groups and others want to see greater oversight of these arrangements to make sure that those processes are transparent and proper. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House:
(1)	 expresses its concern about:
(a)	 the level of accountability and transparency of decisions made under the command and employment powers of the Commissioner of Police under the provisions of the Bill;
(b)	 the lack of mechanisms in the Bill for scrutiny and review of dismissal and promotion decisions;
(c)	 the possible unfair operation of the Bill in relation to termination of employment;
(d)	 the repeal of provisions relating to promotional and advancement systems, and to maternity leave; 

(e)	 the relationship between the command and employment powers of the Commissioner of Police under the Bill;
(f)	 the operation of the Bill in relation to entitlement to continuous employment;
(g)	 clarification of the application of the Workplace Relations Act to the employment regime as established by the Bill; and
(h)	 the failure of the Government to support the establishment of a Parliamentary Joint Committee on Commonwealth law enforcement to provide a strategic view in respect of all Commonwealth law enforcement agencies; and
(2)	 is of the opinion that the Bill should be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and advisory report, given the detailed matters raised in the Bill.

name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
text:
—It is important that law enforcement be provided with the resources and the capacity it needs. In a nation which believes in the rule of law it is vital. Also, in a nation which prides itself on the doctrine of the separation of powers, it is important that those of us in this place provide law enforcement officials with the capacity, the resources and the understanding of issues which are important in the enforcement of laws. We wish them well in their endeavours. We look forward to seeing the AFP continuing their tremendous job.
It is 20 years since the inception of the current incarnation of the Australian Federal Police, but the idea of a national policing body had its roots back in the very earliest of days of this parliament. It was as early as 1903 when some of the ideas were floated. But it was at the time of the celebrated egg throwing incident in Warwick, in my state of Queensland, when Senior Sergeant Kenny, a good Irishman, told Prime Minister Hughes at the time of the great conscription debate he would not intervene to protect the Prime Minister of the day because he worked for another great Irishman in T.J. Ryan, the Labor Premier at the time, that Hughes thought there needed to be some sort of protective mechanism for the Commonwealth. Out of this sketchy tradition came what we have today.
The Australian Federal Police has had, ever since 29 November 1917—it is worth remind 
 ing the House of this particular date; the date of the famous egg throwing incident at Warwick railway station—various incarnations. We had the Commonwealth Investigation Branch from 1919 to 1945. We had the Commonwealth Police Force at one stage, as well. We had the Commonwealth Investigation Service. Since 1979 we have had the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Federal Police do a number of things. One of them is providing police services to the Australian Capital Territory. But it is the provision of police services to enforce the laws of the Commonwealth, to protect the property of the Commonwealth and to safeguard Commonwealth interests in which we in this place are particularly interested.
In my contribution today I want to pay tribute to the efforts of the contemporary members of the Australian Federal Police. I also want to acknowledge that this government is providing them with—as has even been noted by the opposition spokesman the member for Denison—in the words of the Commissioner, Mick Palmer, `resources and capacity far greater, far better, than have ever been provided before'. We do so for a number of reasons. There are great pressures on modern society because criminals seem to be, to use the hackneyed phrase, `one step ahead of the law' because of their capacity to use technology. It is always we legislators who have to react to some new idea of breaking the law, therefore criminals tend to get away with things for a while.
The influx of drugs into this nation has rightly been met with a solid response from the Howard government of new resources, additional resources and a far greater focus being given to the Australian Federal Police, amongst other agencies, enabling there to be, on behalf of all Australians, a far more solid basis on which to combat this most heinous of crimes, this crime which affects the lives of individuals, this trade in human misery—the trade in drugs.
It is important to note for the record some of the great achievements of the Australian Federal Police since the coming to power of the Howard government in 1996. I would like to put those achievements on the record. I 
 admit my source is the Internet, the great electronic device of crime in the late 1990s as well as, one would hope, that great service to humanity where communication is cheap and readily available.
The AFP page heralds so many great achievements over the last couple of years. From Operation Anthem, 23.7 kilos of heroin were found in wall-hangings on their arrival at Melbourne airport and three people were arrested. Through Operations Molotov and Calculus, 8.4 tonnes of cannabis resin were seized in Queensland and there were 15 arrests; 5,000 marijuana plants were also seized at premises of the principal offender. There was the discovery of five tonnes of cannabis in shipping containers in Sydney. There was Operation Redgum in 1996 regarding drug related crimes in the ACT region. Operation Abilene in 1997: a long-running investigation into 624 kilos of compressed cannabis found in a shipping container which was sent from South Africa to Sydney. Seizure of 142 $20 bills, counterfeit polymer banknotes, which were passed in Sydney and Melbourne. Further investigation by the men and women of the Australian Federal Police led to larger counterfeit note seizures, with two people being charged with currency, firearms, stolen vehicle and drug offences. Cyclops in 1997: 10 tonnes of cannabis resin was seized from a vessel near Port Stephens in New South Wales. Twenty kilos of cocaine were discovered in the suitcases of two US citizens arriving in Sydney from Argentina. Also, 23.4 kilos of heroin were found in crates of furniture which travelled from Malaysia to Sydney.
On and on it goes. In 1998, Operation Stockman: a vessel from China smuggled in 94 kilograms of heroin concealed in three industrial ovens in cargo. Chandelier: a consignment of water pumps arrived in Sydney from France and were found to contain 17.2 kilos of ecstasy. Who would forget Operation Gentle from last year when a Customs-AFP joint operation tracked the movements of an international cocaine trafficking syndicate resulting in the seizure of almost 225 kilograms of cocaine from a yacht at Coffs Harbour in New South Wales. Into 
 this year: more ecstasy, more heroin, more heroin, more heroin.
I raise these matters because they go to the heart of what the modern AFP is all about. It is not so much about trying to get some recalcitrant Irishman or a police officer from Queensland in 1917 who would not protect the Prime Minister of the day. It is all about the international linkages and the intelligence which are required to combat crime, to track crime, to use the other agencies which complement it, such as AUSTRAC, the National Crime Authority, Customs and other agencies. This sort of effort by the Australian Federal Police is probably not well appreciated in the broad community.
The Australian Federal Police are not out on the beat, patrolling in the way we wish our state police officers would do—and I know there is a great lament in Queensland with it still not being case. Australian Federal Police officers tend to be people who are brought from other jurisdictions and are hired by the Australian Federal Police because of their intelligence and their ability to dissect potential criminal matters, to perfect the technology which may be used by criminals to try to hide those criminal matters and to actually unpick and unravel matters sufficient for charges to be laid, for prosecutions to commence and for the courts to then judge. The Australian Federal Police are a very special lot—they are an extremely special lot—and they deserve the very best of support from government in their activity.
This bill before us today aims to simplify so many of the existing complex employment provisions under which these special people are brought together under the umbrella of the Australian Federal Police. The provisions in this legislation provide a framework for greater reliance on clear understandings through industrial agreements. They are consistent with the government's overall stated intentions as far as workplace reforms are concerned. We know what those stated intentions are all about. They are all about reward for effort. They are all about ensuring individuals who work hard get the reward they should get. They are about ensuring there is flexibility in workplace arrangements—that 
 people can trade in and out certain agreed standards of employment for some other standard of employment.
Those sorts of basic conditions, those detailed employment conditions, which are determined under the Workplace Relations Act are far more complex than just remuneration alone. It is very important for Australian Federal Police officers to know that the kind of personal individual treatment which can come from the concept of the change to the employment provisions contained in this measure today is all about trying to give them the kind of focus and reward they deserve.
I am on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, like the member for Denison. I am not going to divulge some of the things which we get briefed upon, but when you hear stories about one single Federal Police officer who has dedicated himself to tracking down, with great urgency, some of the details of a crime which he is now able to successfully prosecute and to find great fraud against the Commonwealth because of tax avoidance and those sorts of matters you start to appreciate you here have a person who is not working nine to five, who is not rostered on between eight and four. This is a person who literally broke his emotional back to make things happen. He was not running the sort of bundy clock arrangement of `Clock on, clock off, overtime is now due'. Here is a guy who said, `I've got a job to do. The clock is running, the Commonwealth is losing money, I'm a dedicated police officer and I'm going to work—and I'm going to work until I get this job done.'
 They are the sorts of people that, to my mind, are at the heart of this bill. The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mick Palmer in this current case, should be charged with the responsibility to provide the sort of flexibility that should address those kinds of reasonable concerns from ordinary serving officers. We do not want to see a `one size fits all' approach, a bundy clock type of approach, to industrial relations in this area. It is vital that flexibility exists because there is no way that criminals clock in and out nine to five. The bundy clock does not exist in the criminal world. So it is very important that 
 we offer our representatives in the Australian Federal Police the flexibility they need to do the job they are going to do.
I submit that the legislation before us is worthy of support, because it is part of the overall package of measures this government is putting in place as a whole of government approach in the fight against the trade in human misery, the fight against the trade in illegal drugs coming into this country. They are the reasons that I commend the bill to the House.

name: Schultz, Alby, MP
text:
—I rise to rise to speak on the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999  and, whilst time does not allow me to address all of the amendments, I intend to address some of the issues contained within it. The bill simplifies the existing complex provisions in the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, providing a framework for greater reliance on industrial agreement consistent with the government's workplace reforms. The bill enacts the AFP commissioner's general power of employment, but detailed employment conditions such as remuneration will be determined through agreements in accordance with the Workplace Relations Act 1996.
The bill also recognises and preserves the distinct nature of the AFP as a disciplined force by specifically retaining the commissioner's command powers to the exclusion of the Workplace Relations Act. This is a noble objective, but it will only be as effective as the ability of the commissioner and his line commanders to be professionally committed to the support for the backbone of the AFP front-line troops—the dedicated police officers who, given the appropriate resources, will enforce the law in the same diligent way in which they have done for decades now.
The public has high expectations of police, particularly the AFP, who in my opinion—which is based on knowledge of other police services at a state level—stand head and shoulders above the rest of them. For many years now, much has been said about the need to allocate more resources to the AFP. But at the same time the imposition of so-called efficiency driven cost saving management decisions has seriously curtailed the effective 
 law enforcement capabilities of the professional, dedicated and committed element of the AFP—that is, the police officers themselves.
Governments of all political persuasion have much to answer for in their inability to acknowledge the need to ensure that working conditions as well as adequate resources and remuneration are prerequisites for high morale and motivation not only to achieve the best possible law enforcement outcomes but also to maintain the strength of the force itself, thereby maintaining the incentive to perform to the level expected by the community. Hopefully, these amendments are sufficient to ensure this happens. I do, however, have some reservations about the power carried by the commissioner, because history has shown the top end of management in these organisations have mismanaged the scarce resources at the expense of the front-line officers themselves.
Not long after I came into this place, I raised my concerns about the possibility of 80 per cent of AFP officers on statutory fixed term appointments entitled to the Australian Federal Police Adjustment Scheme, AFPAS, covered in these amendments, resigning from the force. This would have created a massive immediate impact on the ability of government to adequately address the illegal importation and distribution of illicit drugs such as heroin and cocaine, despite the government's well-intentioned and financially committed drug strategy, which should have been addressed a decade ago.
The Howard government has recognised this imminent threat to the decimation of the finest police service in this country by the removal of the statutory fixed term appointment or FTA system. This has impacted to some degree on the rigidity in AFP staffing arrangements and has also impacted negatively on financial management and forward planning. Although to some degree the latter has more to do with lack of management expertise than financial constraints, this is something the government, through its committee structure, needs to investigate if it is to obtain maximum return from the investment 
 made to address, for example, the massive explosion in illicit drugs in this country.
Serving police officers can do the job effectively. However, they need to be guided by forward planning which has both short-term and long-term objectives. The AFP also has to catch up by remunerating its officers in line with salaries comparable with other police services, because salary levels are another element of the disquiet within the force that have to be addressed.
I understand the negotiations regarding salaries are part of the certified agreement discussion currently under way between the AFP and the police association. I trust that these certified agreements or wage negotiations, which are an entirely separate issue, are not linked to the AFPAS to the extent that the AFPAS termination arrangements are used by the commissioner as a lever to extract unfair elements within the certified agreement by the commissioner.
The AFPAS, which is the Australian Federal Police adjustment payment made under the current act, operated as a major incentive for people not to seek reappointment because the AFPAS entitlement is payable only when a person leaves the organisation. The AFPAS was intended to compensate personnel for the loss of further security of employment arising from the FTA system. It was to operate not only as an incentive for people to complete FTAs but also as a corruption deterrent, because it was forfeited if a person was dismissed for corruption or misconduct.
With the replacement of FTAs with a continuing employment regime, the need for an AFPAS disappears. People will make their employment decisions without having to have regard to the artificial constraints imposed by the FTA system and will remove the incentive for a large number of people to leave the AFP in order to access an AFPAS.
If there were a distinct possibility that the considerable powers of the commissioner could be used to determine the time of payment of the AFPAS, the government's sensible decision could be negated and resignations could be revisited. The legislation clearly recognises the AFP as a disciplined organisation in which the commissioner has 
 both the role of a public sector chief executive officer and, more importantly, a commander in every sense of the word. The amendments will enable the commissioner and the organisation to adequately respond to emerging management and law enforcement trends in a rapidly changing environment where the pace of change is going to increase.
The capacity of both the organisation and the police serving in it to not only anticipate change but also participate in those changes in an environment of high morale and with a commitment to achieve the outcomes expected by the community is essential to maintaining the integrity of what I believe to be the most corruption free and professional police service in the nation. These amendments will enable further development of this capacity while appropriately safeguarding the interests of the members of the organisation.
The public—and, I am sure, all members in this place—understand that the extraordinary demands of police work require high ethical standards. We are all aware of the complex and often dangerous circumstances associated with investigating organised crime involved in drug trafficking and related activities and the dangers involved in community policing. This is all the more reason why we have to ensure these amendments not only enforce the integrity of the AFP but also have the ability to attract the right people into the organisation.
Last year the government announced its Tough on Drugs strategy. Included in the funding which came with this announcement was a provision to finance the recruitment of about 50 federal agents from within the ranks of serving police officers. Despite advertisements being placed in national newspapers, the response was disappointing given that there are approximately 41,000 police serving in police services throughout Australia. This has everything to do with remuneration and is a classic illustration of why the level of recruitment over the years has not kept pace with resignations.
The point I am making here is that we must always keep in mind that any amendments to legislation must not only address the issue of accountability for misconduct, testing for 
 drugs and other employment related matters but always address the issue of adequate rates of pay and working conditions that reflect the nation's appreciation of its front-line national police service, which provides the highly motivated and skilled operators who make up the backbone of the AFP.
Obviously, these amendments have focused on the need to lift morale within the driving edge of the AFP by tightening the standards centred around the powers, duties, obligations and responsibilities of AFP employees, including its police officers. In the past, former commissioners and ministers of the Crown have obtained much public political mileage by espousing that the AFP has been underresourced and that the upgrading of police resources and conditions was critical to the development of an effective means for society to not only control and prevent organised crime but allow the AFP to become more proactive in preventing, detecting and destroying it before it destroys the very fabric of our society. As an example of what I am talking about, Major General Ron Grey—who was appointed AFP Commissioner in February 1983—wrote in his first annual report:
Organisational change cannot alone compensate for deficiencies in resources . . . Resources need to be brought more into balance with demands of the Force.
In the period 1984-85, following a national drug summit in the ACT and the Costigan royal commission presenting its final report, Commissioner Grey wrote:
In my view drug trafficking and organised crime emerge as the areas needing more resources . . . I remain very concerned that scarce AFP resources are being siphoned off to support such organisations as the DPP and the NCA . . . Shortages of manpower and funds remain my major concern.
We are talking about a decline in attitude towards the AFP and its most precious resource, its front-line police. That decline—despite what the member for Denison was saying, as the shadow minister for justice and customs, about the current government's lack of commitment to the AFP as such—happened in the mid-1980s, and the decline has continued since then. It is a question that needs to be addressed by all governments if 
 we are to be serious about the massive influx of illicit drugs into this country.
We only have to look at what is happening in Victoria at the moment. An enormous amount of cocaine is coming into Victoria, and I have absolutely no doubt that it will be coming in elsewhere. Dedicated AFP police officers cannot possibly cope with that sort of pressure unless they are adequately resourced, particularly well-trained and capable police offices. It is important that they use their detection and surveillance skills to get on top of this very serious problem.
Let me now refer to a former member of this House, Mr Gareth Evans. When Attorney-General, the then Senator Gareth Evans summed up the conclusions of the 1983 National Crime Commission Conference with the following:
I discerned no disagreement about the fact that police are under resourced . . . There was a general acknowledgment that upgrading of police resources, methods and machinery must be part of any solution to the problem of organised crime . . . It is a question of resources that can and should be made available to police . . . A question to which Government, including I acknowledge the Commonwealth Government, must address their collective minds very quickly.
These legislative amendments will at least go towards addressing some of the workplace related reforms and will be complemented by the certified agreements reached between the commissioner and the AFP association on behalf of its members.
As I said earlier, the commissioner needs to focus on instilling confidence in his organisation, which for years now has been let down because of a continual focus on cost cutting through efficiency programs that tend to curtail the ability of police, for example, to effectively use their considerable law enforcement and investigatory skills to impact on the massive drug trade in this country. There is still a long way to go and, while governments can make the funding available to ensure that their policies on law enforcement are carried out, this will amount to absolutely nothing unless the obvious problems with the management and administrative functions of the AFP are addressed.
Today is not the day for me to elaborate on these issues. The bill before the House limits my contribution on matters associated with the failure of the AFP management to focus its energies and forward planning on what has driven the low morale and threatened the mass resignations which this bill, to the credit of the Minister for Justice and Customs, has to some extent overcome. At some time in the future, I will raise these issues. This will hopefully motivate senior AFP managers to address the deficiencies created by what I believe to be inadequate levels of skilled investigators, low levels of operational police, a lack of transfer of highly motivated skilled investigators within their ranks both inter and intrastate and a general feeling of despair created by poor personnel management. I thank the House for its indulgence in allowing me to speak on this issue. It has assisted me in raising matters that highlight the difficulties being faced by the backbone of the AFP—the front-line police officers themselves. I support the bill.

name: Baird, Bruce, MP
text:
—It is my pleasure tonight to rise in support of the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . It is significant legislation and I congratulate Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice and Customs, in having the foresight to address the particular problems and issues that now confront the Australian Federal Police and in introducing a new era in human resources management in the Australian Federal Police. The AFP has operated very much like a bureaucracy. In terms of the contracts that have been offered to the police, if police officers terminated and took a payout at the end of their contract, this would be a significant blow to the police force in the estimated numbers of police that they would lose. Some 10 per cent of police officers, at least, would be expected to resign within a one-year period if all of the contracts that are now in place were activated in terms of the payout that was expected to be made.
The Australian Federal Police is a very fine organisation that deserves the support of every member of this House. As someone with a brother who was a member of the NSW Police Force, I am aware of the issues 
 that confront police on a daily basis. It is an occupation which is very demanding, challenging and, in many cases, dangerous. It has an impact on people and, certainly, as those people who have seen police go through very traumatic events will know, this can often leave an imprint on their life for a very significant time. In recognising the Australian Federal Police here tonight, I think it is important for us to not only see them as upholders of the law—in, for example, ensuring that drugs do not enter the country illegally—looking after policing in all its various aspects in the ACT and nationally, but also to look beyond that and see them as individuals who have similar needs to other Australians in terms of their personal security, financial security and the way in which they are treated.
This bill goes a long way towards addressing these issues and implementing them in legislation. This will bring the Australian Federal Police into line with contemporary organisations. Clearly, the normal public service requirements are different from those of the Australian Federal Police—aspects of some of the personal freedoms that we would expect in the public service and in other organisations in the private sector are not present in the Australian Federal Police. Some of those freedoms will be forfeited by people as a result of being in the police force. That aside, however, this bill is about opening up the Australian Federal Police and making it subject to the same types of workplace relations agreements that we have seen in other areas of the economy.
It is important to see this bill as about preserving the core values of the Australian Federal Police and the commissioner in achieving the organisation's values of integrity, commitment, excellence, accountability, fairness and trust. The commissioner has a difficult time in meeting all of those requirements in terms of his or her objectives. But that is what this legislation is all about. It is clear to the government that the public expects the organisation to measure up to its high expectations in terms of commitment and excellence. It demonstrated these qualities when 50 Australian Federal Police officers 
 went to East Timor during August and September of this year to take part in CIVPOL, the multinational team ensuring security in East Timor before and during the independence vote.
Domestically, the Australian Federal Police's most high profile roles are providing policing services to the ACT, providing witness protection nationally and combating drug trafficking, fraud, organised crime and money laundering. It has had a number of successes in recent years, including Operation Linnet. This operation disrupted the activities of a major international drug trafficking organisation through the seizure of 390 kilograms of heroin in October 1998. It was also involved in an international joint operation with authorities from Canada and Hong Kong. This operation seized a further 163 kilograms of heroin in a number of raids in 1998 and 1999. Operation Bronte, a joint operation between the AFP and DIMA, resulted in the detention in May this year of 83 unlawful non-citizens aboard a specifically modified freighter through the interception of maps and other documents at Sydney airport. I am sure that you would agree that this was an outstanding job. In anybody's language, they should be commended for their great achievements in drug enforcement.
The Australian Federal Police are also responding to changing trends. They must relate to those changing trends in criminal activity and, to do that, they must be a flexible organisation. Rapid and easy transportation systems, new communications systems, worldwide financial linkages and the progressive removal of border controls combined with increased trade volumes are factors which increase the challenge faced by the AFP. The dynamic and unpredictable nature of criminal activity means that they need to be constantly changing their approach to be able to carry out the apprehension of crime that we look for in the AFP. In addition to his responsibilities as commissioner of the AFP—as the CEO of the organisation—the commissioner's performance is measured in terms of the overall management and performance of the organisation itself. He also oper 
 ates subject to the requirements of public sector accountabilities.
As to the specific reforms mentioned in the bill, an additional $115 million will be provided over three years to assist the Australian Federal Police to increase their staffing, maximise their capabilities and concentrate resources on fighting crime. A particularly important feature is, of course, the flexible employment arrangements. The Australian Federal Police now come under a workplace arrangement, which is the way most organisations now negotiate in the private sector. The commissioner becomes the employer—as he would in the private sector—and they negotiate with him as conditions apply. It is a sensible arrangement. It shows flexible thinking, foresight and good management of human resources.
The bill ensures that the commissioner is treated specially where the Australian Federal Police is unique but that the organisation is subject to the same discipline as applies to other bodies where it is not. The amendments recognise the need for a balance between general public sector and workplace issues and the need to recognise the unique situation applying to the Federal Police. The bill invests the commissioner with a general employment power in addition to ensuring that more flexible and efficient workplace arrangements can be implemented. It separates the role of command and discipline from matters relating to employment. It also enables the commissioner to deploy Australian Federal Police employees and to assign duties. This reinforces an important element in commanding a police organisation in both domestic and international activities. There are also strong anticorruption measures in the bill, and I think they would receive the support of every member of the House.
One of the major initiatives is the removal of the statutory fixed term appointment system, known as the FTA system. As I mentioned before, this has created a problem with fixed arrangements. It is not unusual in the private sector to have fixed term arrangements and contracts, often for three or five years, but the problem with this piece of legislation is that two aspects of fixed term 
 agreements were untenable. The first one is that the majority of agreements were due for renewal or termination during a one-year period. The second is the incentive attached to the renewal of these contracts which would make it very attractive for people to resign and maximise their own earnings. It allows individuals to take up a lump sum payment which is triggered only on resignation.
If a number of people in the Australian Federal Police are due for re-endorsement of their contracts during the one period and then there is the incentive to get out, what do you think is likely to happen? The answer is that you are going to lose a lot of very fine policemen—policemen who have been trained and have been in all types of situations with the enormous breadth of experience that we see in the Australian Federal Police. It is something that the nation should not be subjected to—something that we should avoid. Both the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice and Customs need to be congratulated on recognising the problem and making the appropriate changes to the way the whole system is operated.
Whilst it is not possible to provide a definitive figure on how many of the AFP's 2,800 staff would quit following the end of their fixed terms, an educated guess is that it would be around 10 per cent. If 280 people resigned at any one time from the Federal Police it would be a significant loss to the organisation and would jeopardise the overall performance of a very fine organisation.
AFPAS was intended to compensate personnel for the future loss of employment security arising from the FTA system. It was to operate as an incentive for people to complete their contracts as well as to add to an anticorruption measure. If they did not reach the end of their contract or were precluded from taking up the contract because they had been involved in some corrupt practices, clearly the financial incentive would be important as an anticorruption measure. This has been replaced as part of a continuing employment regime. Under a new workplace agreement, they can now negotiate how they should operate directly with the commissioner. This has resulted in the renegotiation of 
 their general conditions. The $115 million, which is to be provided over three years, will result in a better human resources management environment.
There have been some criticisms by members of the opposition of this particular piece of legislation: firstly, the termination of employment by the commissioner and, secondly, the reasons for dismissal. Proposed section 28 of the bill provides that the commissioner may, at any time by notice in writing, terminate the employment of an AFP employee. Item 1 of schedule 2 to the bill amends the administrative decisions such that, should the commissioner exercise his or her power to dismiss an AFP employee under section 28, the commissioner is not required to give reasons for that dismissal under the act. Of course, it is important to recognise that all rights in relation to unfair dismissal contained in division 3 of part VIA of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 apply for dismissals under section 28 of the bill. These rights include and allow for the provision of reasonable notice and reasons for dismissal.
Then there is the question of the commissioner's orders not being disallowable instruments.
