It is proposed that, under section 38 of the bill, the commissioner may, in writing, issue orders with respect to the general administration and control of the operations of the AFP. It re-enacts the power to make general orders and general instructions contained in section 14 of the AFP Act. The power to issue orders with respect to the general administration and control of the operations of the AFP is fundamental to the commissioner's command of a disciplined force. It is essentially a legislative recognition of a common law power recognised by the courts.
The parliament has chosen deliberately to operate at arms length from the Australian Federal Police. It cannot on the one hand say that it is operating at arms length and on the other say that it wants to have the disallowable instrument revived. There is a need to be independent. The importance of an independent police force, where command decisions are made by the commissioner, is undermined if the commissioner's orders are subject to 
 parliamentary disallowance. That independence should be sacrosanct. An independent police force means a better operating police force. An independent police force will ensure the integrity overall of the police force and should be supported. These criticisms by the opposition are not sustainable.
There was also the question of the partial removal of the privilege against self-incrimination in relation to the commissioner's orders and other integrity measures. Clearly, there is some concern about the obligation to comply with these orders and with any lawful direction, instruction or order presently in the AFP, and that requirement has been moved into the act. Where an AFP employee or special member is required to give information, answer a question or produce a document in relation to the commissioner's order or a lawful direction, instruction or order, they are not excused on the grounds of self-incrimination.
On the whole, it is a question of the individual and the rights of the individual as opposed to the importance of having an organisation of integrity which is corruption free and has the ability, where there are suspicions of wrongdoing within the organisation, to compel individual police officers to give evidence. Even if it may affect their employment within that organisation, under the requirements of this act, it does not affect any matter that can be taken to court.
It is only an internal provision. It is aimed at ensuring a situation where leads can be followed up and officers can be interrogated. Even if it does mean some self-incrimination, I am sure that, above all, we would want to have an Australian Federal Police which is as corruption free as possible. Living in the real world, we all know that that is always difficult. Despite the fact there are objections from the police union and there may be some concerns, I believe that, on balance, it is an appropriate line of action to take.
The integrity measures under the AFP Act are different from those applicable to other public servants, employees generally or members of the public. In the case of the Police Service Board v. Morris, it was identified that the police service is a public service 
 where members voluntarily undertake the curtailment of freedoms they would otherwise enjoy. It is also incumbent on the commissioner to take a proactive approach to the system of integrity.
The protections in relation to the powers that the commissioner would have limit the circumstances in which information obtained by compulsion may be used in evidence. The AFP disciplinary regulations create a disciplinary offence for the improper use of information. The Privacy Act 1988 regulates the collection, use, disclosure and storage of personal information. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 provides that a complaint may be made to the ombudsman concerning action taken by a deputy commissioner. The protections and safeguards are in place.
We have before us a bill which, I believe, is an enlightened piece of legislation. It enables Australian Federal Police officers to be treated in a way that is not dissimilar from the private sector in terms of their ability to negotiate directly with the commissioner. But, of course, it is subject to the Public Service requirements and to the special conditions that relate to police services around the world. It enables flexibility so we do not have the situation where we have fixed contracts and then people being terminated, losing those significant resources. The legislation before us protects individuals appearing before inquiries and will ensure that our Australian Federal Police service is one of integrity and as corruption free as possible. I commend this bill to the House.
Motion (by Ms Ellis) negatived:
That the debate be adjourned.
—As your motion has been negatived, you now have the right to speak to the bill as you are on the speakers list. Do you wish to speak?
—No, Mr Deputy Speaker.

name: Williams, Daryl, MP
text:
—I am very pleased to be winding up the debate on the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . One thing I regret is that, despite the importance of the bill, there has been little 
 interest shown in it by the members of the opposition. In fact, the member for Canberra, who just sought to change the agenda of the parliament, was down to speak but did not rise to speak on the bill.
As I said, this is an important bill. It is a bill designed to modernise and simplify the Australian Federal Police Act. It builds on the existing strengths of the AFP and will deliver flexibility within a framework that will build on the expertise and professionalism of the AFP as Australia's premier police force. In fact, it is part of a package of measures designed to achieve the Prime Minister's objective of having a world-class police force as our Australian Federal Police. The bill recognises the distinctive employment relationship within the AFP, where the commissioner has both command and employment powers, unlike those of other employers. It is incumbent upon police managers of a disciplined force to implement a proactive system of integrity testing to exclude any potential for corruption.
The provisions in the bill for drug testing and disclosure of financial information, while they would ordinarily be seen as a restriction on personal freedoms, represent the community expectations of a police force free from corruption and open to scrutiny. I can recall a couple of years ago, when I had the office of Minister for Justice as well as the office of Attorney-General, launching the voluntary drug testing scheme that was instituted by the commissioner with the support of the Australian Federal Police Association. This was something that the members of the Australian Federal Police were happy to support because it gave the appearance of integrity as well as the test for actuality.
The bill does not take away any rights in relation to unfair dismissal that are available under the Workplace Relations Act 1996. AFP employees will have a right to reasonable notice of termination of employment under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and also to reasons for termination. The Industrial Relations Commission has made it clear in a number of decisions that in order for a dismissal to be fair reasons must be given. Where an adverse revelation or discovery is 
 made through mandatory drug testing or financial disclosure, the commissioner will continue to have a range of discretionary powers at his disposal—from counselling to opportunities for rehabilitation and investigation through to dismissal. This will allow the commissioner to respond in a manner commensurate with the individual's circumstances yet maintain the commissioner's disciplinary responsibilities.
The role of the parliament remains unchanged, with the current convention continuing, whereby ministerial directions under section 13—section 37 in the bill—are tabled. Additionally, such directions will continue to be published in the AFP's annual report. The amendments proposed in the bill reinforce the special nature of policing and provide adequate protections both for AFP employees and the community, to ensure that the AFP continues to maintain its leading role in law enforcement.
The member for Denison, in responding on behalf of the opposition, asserted that there was a lack of clarity between dealing with the employment powers and the command powers vested in the commissioner under the proposed legislation. In fact, the purpose of the bill is to achieve clarity in relation to those two categories of power. The current act intermingles command and employment issues to a point of confusion as to where the commissioner's powers of command and his responsibilities as an employer stand. The bill rectifies these inflexibilities and uncertainties by providing a clear distinction between command and employment issues, with the result of greater certainty.
The member for Denison raised the question of his request for a referral of the bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The member for Denison is well aware, from his former role as Minister for Justice in the Keating government, that I am very keen to see House standing committees consider legislation rather than leaving it to Senate committees. It would have been consistent with my preference that the bill be inquired into and reported on by the House committee 
 rather than leaving it, as is often the case, to a Senate committee to do a rush job.
However, in the circumstances of the House committee, the request, coming as late as it did, was not feasible. The House committee is considering a number of references already, including a reference on copyright enforcement, a reference on the Copyright Amendment (Digital Agenda) Bill 1999  and another reference on a matter relating to genetic modification that was given by another minister. On that basis, our inquiries indicated that the House committee would not be able to deal with the matter within a reasonable time frame in order to ensure that this bill was dealt with by the Senate before the end of the year, as the government desires.
The result of this aspect is that the bill will be referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report, and I am told that the committee will report by 6 December 1999. The issues nominated by the member for Denison, as the shadow minister, will be considered by the Senate committee. I suggest, therefore, to the member for Denison that any matter to be referred to the House committee, being consistent with my personal preference for matters in my portfolio, be made a little earlier than this one was.
